It is difficult to talk about collaboration without talking about being social. After all, collaboration is defined as “working with another person or group in order to achieve or do something.” That sounds social – doesn’t it?

For the last several months we’ve outlined our approach to Enterprise Collaboration Strategy and Roadmaps and discussed details in areas from governance, training and communication, to user experience and usability, to making sure you have the right technology foundation in place. This final piece in our series will dig into social and mobile as factors in an Enterprise Collaboration Roadmap.

WHAT IS SOCIAL, ANYWAY?
In the enterprise, social and social business mean different things to different people. Every organization is at a different level of social maturity, and readiness to embrace social capabilities. In creating an Enterprise Collaboration Roadmap, we look at a wide range of social capabilities, as well as cultural issues that may impact a social strategy and adoption. Topics include:

  • Is the culture receptive to modern social business capabilities? What are some foreseeable obstacles? What level of change management will be needed?
  • How do employees find subject matter experts?
  • What information is contained in an employee’s profile? Are skills, projects, hobbies, areas of expertise, etc. included?
  • Are wikis and blogs used? Are they highly adopted across the organization?
  • How can online communities be used to facilitate more efficient interaction between individuals with a common purpose?
  • Would newsfeed type functionality be valuable?
  • Can users rate, follow, tag or highlight content?
  • How is ideation performed? Would crowdsourcing improve the quality and number of ideas?
  • What type of recognition programs are in place? Can the Enterprise Collaboration environment be leveraged?
  • Are users using “external” social tools for business purposes, such as Yammer, Jive, LinkedIn, etc., that run the risk of exposing confidential information?

COLLABORATION REQUIRES MOBILE
In a previous post, “Social and Mobile must be part of ALL Digital Solutions“, we discussed how mobile (and social) must be part of any solution. This applies to an Enterprise Collaboration Roadmap as well – mobile must be a significant consideration in all areas of the roadmap. Like social, mobile often has different meanings which we explore through questions like:

  • How are employees in the field collaborating with each other?
  • What information, processes, and applications do remote users require?
  • What content is accessed on each type of device? Phones? Tablets? Laptop?
  • How do tablet and phone users interact with social content? How do they find experts?
  • How can a consistent user experience across all devices provide better usability and higher adoption?
  • Are there strong use cases for apps and/or applications? Which is best?

  • What key security considerations are there for mobile?

Understanding where your organization is heading with social and mobile is especially critical because these two areas are rapidly spreading through the enterprise. If they aren’t already, users will soon demand social and mobile capabilities, and those demands will only increase as users have broader online experiences outside of work. Do you have a roadmap for mobile and social in your company?

The post Enterprise Users Demand Social and Mobile appeared first on TahoeSmart.

item.title: HealthCare.gov Subsidy Eligibility Application Tour
item.dc:creator: Erin Yamaoka
item.description:
The Health Insurance Marketplace is off to a rocky start. However, as Eric Gundersen (President of Development Seed, a government sub-contractor responsible

The post HealthCare.gov Subsidy Eligibility Application Tour appeared first on TahoeSmart.
item.content:encoded:
The Health Insurance Marketplace is off to a rocky start. However, as Eric Gundersen (President of Development Seed, a government sub-contractor responsible for some of the front end work on HealthCare.gov) said in an interview with the Washington Post, “This is going to get fixed. This is a lot of scale. They got, in 24 hours, more people trying to register than Twitter got users in 24 months. Do you remember how many fail whales [Twitter error messages] there were then?”

While the number of individuals rushing to shop the Marketplace is impressive, Gundersen’s observation may not ameliorate the process for the 250,000 simultaneous users trying to apply for assistance and enroll in coverage.

Take a look at the HealthCare.gov Subsidy Eligibility Application process – without waiting in line. Here’s a sneak peak:

For the latest news on Healthcare.gov, including user experience and integration options, subscribe to our blog or contact Amy Widicus.

item.title: Oscar and Other Disruptive Technologies
item.dc:creator: Mukesh Pitroda
item.description:
In a recent post on Health Insurance and Innovation, we predicted the rise of small, niche healthcare companies with a mission to

The post Oscar and Other Disruptive Technologies appeared first on TahoeSmart.
item.content:encoded:
In a recent post on Health Insurance and Innovation, we predicted the rise of small, niche healthcare companies with a mission to engage consumers with transparent, interactive applications. One such startup is Oscar, a new entrant in New York’s health insurance market. Their goal: to “make insurance simple, intuitive, and human.”

As part of our ongoing series on innovation in the health insurance industry, we took a look at Oscar’s website and insurance quote tool. Watch the video to find out what we liked, as well as some lessons that large, traditional insurers can apply to their digital retail strategy.

The post Oscar and Other Disruptive Technologies appeared first on TahoeSmart.

item.title: Enterprise Collaboration: User Experience and Change Resilient Design
item.dc:creator: Mike Davidson
item.description:
When we begin to talk about enterprise collaboration, almost every company quickly mentions their challenges with usability and adoption. It’s a common

The post Enterprise Collaboration: User Experience and Change Resilient Design appeared first on TahoeSmart.
item.content:encoded:
When we begin to talk about enterprise collaboration, almost every company quickly mentions their challenges with usability and adoption. It’s a common theme because most technology environments grow organically as needs arise, and user experience falls victim to technology transition and business evolution. As we approach a redesign and begin creating an Enterprise Collaboration roadmap, we look closely at the current and future challenges of organizational change, and building a ‘change resilient’ design.

Factors of Organization Change

 

A Change Resilient Design
A top redesign objective is creating a stable Information Architecture that evolves in an elegant manner, anticipates scale, and is resilient to flux. It begins with a shift in design philosophy: we design navigation for people not companies. Contemporary navigation presents categories by user intention versus organizational silo.

Companies often design top-level navigation based on organizational structure – departments, business units, or org charts. This makes the content architecture highly susceptible to change. As a solution, we rethink navigation from the employee’s perspective, tailoring the experience to the individual and to their unique role, supporting how they work. This task-based design results in a more stable content architecture, and an experience that is better suited to performing specific tasks. Navigation can never be all things to all people, but we can tailor views and provide personalization that better meets each user’s unique needs.

In planning a roadmap, we consider the various roles, jobs, and departments within your company. The breadth and depth of understanding your enterprise users is a significant factor in scoping budget and timelines. This activity is commonly referred to as User Definition, and it is the foundation for the design process and a key element of improving adoption and productivity. We ask questions like:

  • How many user types exist within your company?
  • Which are primary versus secondary user groups? (Value to business)
  • What are their working conditions, unique tasks, and content interactions?

Understanding these and other insights will result in a more intelligent design and improved usability. This information can be gathered through interviews and observation; the rigor of this process varies and is a scope consideration. One option is to view the process as iterative, defining users with initial broad strokes and refining the details over time – improving efficiency, adding functionality and tailoring experiences.

A tenet of great web design is to view your Intranet as a living, breathing entity. There is no end to the project, only phases and new releases. Build your Enterprise Collaboration roadmap with this philosophy in mind, and you will always be adding value, improving performance and gaining adoption.

The post Enterprise Collaboration: User Experience and Change Resilient Design appeared first on TahoeSmart.

item.title: Don’t Wait for your Customers to Call You
item.dc:creator: Jeff Bustamante
item.description:
For many health insurers, enticing policyholders to use their member portal site has been both a top priority and a continual challenge.

The post Don’t Wait for your Customers to Call You appeared first on TahoeSmart.
item.content:encoded:
For many health insurers, enticing policyholders to use their member portal site has been both a top priority and a continual challenge. In spite of the wealth of information and tools available, it is difficult to convince members to log in and take advantage of these benefits.

It’s time to move beyond relying on email and print campaigns, promotions, and new mobile applications to attract customers to the member portal, and work towards delivering products and services tailored to what’s going on in their world… at exactly the right moment.

Imagine a scenario where you receive an email when your child turns fifteen, with tips on teaching your son or daughter to be a responsible driver. You might see a text message listing the Top 10 things to do when planning to have a baby – triggered by purchasing an ovulation kit with your flexible spending account. Or after moving to a new home, you get an email notification providing a list of in-network, primary care physicians, pharmacies, and health clubs in your new neighborhood.

Life events are milestones that are likely to prompt some type of interaction between an individual and their insurance provider. Health insurance related life events include:

  • Starting a new job
  • Getting married
  • Giving birth or adopting a child
  • Reaching age 26
  • Diagnosis of a serious illness
  • Planning major surgery

These major life events can be a fruitful time to reach out to consumers. The key is utilizing the data that is already available to your organization in a way that feels helpful, not intrusive. Health insurers have member-level claims and spending account data, which can be leveraged to proactively contact members at the appropriate time. For example, a diabetes diagnosis might prompt a phone call from a disease management clinician, with advice on living with and treating diabetes. Used correctly, life event triggers can lead to better care at a lower cost for the member and, ultimately, lower costs for insurers.

An organization that can successfully engage consumers with a life event-based member experience will hold the key to providing better overall customer care, as well as reducing the costs associated with maintaining a more reactive customer service approach.

In short, you no longer have the luxury of waiting for customers to reach out to you.

The post Don’t Wait for your Customers to Call You appeared first on TahoeSmart.

item.title: First Look: Open Enrollment Outpaces Expectations
item.dc:creator: Mukesh Pitroda
item.description:
This week marked the most significant implementation of the Affordable Care Act – the opening of federal and state exchanges to facilitate

The post First Look: Open Enrollment Outpaces Expectations appeared first on TahoeSmart.
item.content:encoded:
This week marked the most significant implementation of the Affordable Care Act – the opening of federal and state exchanges to facilitate the purchase of health care insurance. Approximately 50 million Americans are currently without health insurance and since Tuesday, have demonstrated significant interest in what these exchanges have to offer.

If the first day of the exchanges seemed mired in glitches, it may have been due in part to an unexpected influx of visitors to these sites. Initial numbers from federal officials counted 2.8 million visitors to healthcare.gov as of late afternoon Tuesday. State-based exchanges also saw high traffic; with over 2 million people navigating to New York’s exchange within the first few hours, and California reporting approximately 5 million views before 3:00 PST.

Some of these numbers may have been inaccurate, as was the case in California, where the initial number was later revised to 645,000. Even as the final data remains to be calculated and verified, there seems to be significant interest in the health insurance marketplace among the presently uninsured and individual buyers. For example, in the same time period that the federal exchange website received 2.8 million visitors, they also received 81,000 calls. Hawaii’s state exchange site, Hawaii Health Connector, indicated that it has received over 1200 applications to date.

Ultimately, the numbers that matter the most are the number of people who enroll. So far, the federal government isn’t releasing information on how many people have signed up for health insurance via the new exchange. Not to mention that this week is only the first few days of a months-long purchase period.

Nearly 65% of the more than 50 million uninsured Americans have indicated an interest in purchasing health care insurance by December 15 – the cutoff date to enroll in the new policies taking effect on January 1, 2014. However, HHS officials expect only 7 million people to sign up for individual coverage within the next year.

Will the state and federal exchanges continue to draw huge numbers of visitors? Can the infrastructure of the exchanges sustain such high traffic? Will we see the number of new enrollees far exceed projections? We’ll report back periodically as we learn more.

The post First Look: Open Enrollment Outpaces Expectations appeared first on TahoeSmart.

item.title: Enterprise Collaboration: How to Simplify and Maximize Your Platform
item.dc:creator: David Sidwell
item.description:
Does your organization have multiple systems or platforms providing overlapping collaboration capabilities? Do users know which systems to use, and when? Do

The post Enterprise Collaboration: How to Simplify and Maximize Your Platform appeared first on TahoeSmart.
item.content:encoded:
Does your organization have multiple systems or platforms providing overlapping collaboration capabilities? Do users know which systems to use, and when? Do these systems have untapped resources that could provide additional benefit if properly implemented?

As part of our ongoing look at the makings of an Enterprise Collaboration Strategy and Roadmap, we’re exploring the ways an Enterprise Collaboration Strategy can improve adoption and boost ROI by aligning the use of tools, platforms, and applications.

ENTERPRISE COLLABORATION CAPABILITIES
Enterprise Collaboration goes beyond document management and social tools, encompassing all of the following:

  • Document Management
  • Collaboration
  • Intranets and Extranets
  • Social Business
  • Mobile Access
  • Workflow and Process Automation
  • Personalization
  • Unified Communications
  • Forms Management
  • Search
  • Business Intelligence
  • Records Management
  • Web Content Management

With such a large set of capabilities, it is easy to understand why many companies are not using their Enterprise Collaboration platform to its fullest potential. Often, organizations are not aware of the potential uses, or lack proper governance to determine which capabilities should be applied and when.

When creating an Enterprise Collaboration Strategy, we look at how a company is using their current platform(s) – evaluating how available tools can be used in new ways, and which capabilities should be discontinued. What existing assets could provide more benefits to users? How can we increase adoption? Make processes more efficient? Increase ROI?

DOES ANYONE HAVE JUST ONE ENTERPRISE COLLABORATION PLATFORM?
Enterprise Collaboration solutions are incorporated into the enterprise systems that users interact with daily. For example, Salesforce has document management and social tools; SharePoint is well known for document management, as well as social and workflow (among others); Jive offers many of the same capabilities; and project management tools often have some capacity for document management and workflow. With multiple systems providing overlapping capabilities, users become confused and ask questions like:

  • Where should I store documents to share them with my team?
  • Where do I find documents about product development, sales or other areas?
  • Where do I post micro-blogs and see what others are posting?
  • Which workflow tool should be used to automate this process?
  • How do I best collaborate and share documents with external parties?
  • Where do I place documents that I want to work on from home?
  • Do records go into SharePoint like my other documents?

Essentially, what users are asking is, “what system should I use for which purpose?” Further, IT and legal are left to ask how content is managed and controlled in each system. To evaluate this, we often use a tool called the Platform Usage Matrix, which documents the primary uses of each platform, as well as the primary platform for each enterprise collaboration capability.

What are some key areas to consider as you look at your Enterprise Collaboration environment? A good Enterprise Collaboration Strategy looks at the tools used across the organization, evaluates how they can best be used (or not), and makes a plan for communicating these best practices to users – ensuring that you are making the most of each platform.

Read more from our series on Enterprise Collaboration Strategy and Roadmaps, including building the right technology foundation, content and search, and governance, training and communication.

The post Enterprise Collaboration: How to Simplify and Maximize Your Platform appeared first on TahoeSmart.

item.title: Shopping the Health Insurance Exchange: What does it mean to me?
item.dc:creator: Jeri Stroupe
item.description:
With state and federal exchanges opening for business under the Affordable Care Act, tomorrow marks the first time millions of Americans will

The post Shopping the Health Insurance Exchange: What does it mean to me? appeared first on TahoeSmart.
item.content:encoded:
With state and federal exchanges opening for business under the Affordable Care Act, tomorrow marks the first time millions of Americans will have the ability to shop, compare plans, and identify if they are eligible for a Premium Credit. Many eligible individuals have heard they can now “shop the exchange” but may still be asking, what does this mean to me?

What do those who plan to shop the health insurance marketplace need to know?

When can I enroll?
The Open Enrollment period for exchange plans begins October 1, 2013 and will end on March 31, 2014.

What are the penalties if I don’t enroll in health insurance?
The ACA requires all Americans to have insurance coverage by January 1, 2014, or risk incurring penalties of 1% of yearly income or $95 per person per year, whichever is higher. In 2016, this fee is set to increase to 2.5% of income or $695 person, whichever is higher. For uninsured children, parents will incur a penalty of $47.50 per child. It’s also important to note that any individual not covered by a health insurance plan is responsible for 100% of any medical bills they incur.

Am I eligible for a tax credit?
By shopping the exchange, consumers can find out if they are eligible for Medicaid or a Premium credit. Individuals with income below $45,960, and married couples earning less than $94,200 are eligible for tax credits.

What types of plans are offered on the Exchange?
There are four different types of plans available for purchase on the exchange: Bronze, Silver, Gold and Platinum. With a Bronze plan, insurers will pay 60% of medical costs; Silver is 70% covered; Gold is 80% covered; and Platinum plans cover 90% of medical costs. The Affordable Care Act sets minimum standards for what insurance plans must cover by defining essential health benefits. Exchange plans must comply with these requirements in order to be considered a Qualified Health Plan (QHP) and be sold on the Marketplace. Some essential health benefits include:

  • Ambulatory Patient Services
  • Emergency Room Services
  • Hospitalization
  • Laboratory Services
  • Maternity and Newborn Care
  • Mental Health and Substance Use Disorders
  • Pediatric Services and Chonic Disease Management
  • Prescription Drugs
  • Preventative and Wellness Services
  • Chronic Disease Management
  • Rehabilitation and Habilitative Services and Devices

Will you be shopping the exchange on October 1?

The post Shopping the Health Insurance Exchange: What does it mean to me? appeared first on TahoeSmart.

item.title: Why is McKinsey Bullish on Digital?
item.dc:creator: Ralph Keipert
item.description:
A recent global survey of C-level executives by McKinsey suggests that CXOs are stepping up their efforts in shaping and driving digital

The post Why is McKinsey Bullish on Digital? appeared first on TahoeSmart.
item.content:encoded:
A recent global survey of C-level executives by McKinsey suggests that CXO s are stepping up their efforts in shaping and driving digital strategies. These are 4 of the top 5 areas where executives expect their companies to realize benefits from digital business:

  • Digital engagement of customers
  • Digital innovation
  • Digital engagement of employees, suppliers and partners
  • Automation

What is digital?
Not to be confused with traditional information technology solutions that primarily automate discrete business transactions – from our perspective, digital solutions are best described by words like web, mobile and social. Digital solutions done well effectively engage key internal and external audiences, automate collaborative workflow, and put the value of enterprise information to work.

Where are the priorities?
It’s not surprising that customer engagement ranks as a top priority. More than half of respondents indicate that digital engagement of customers is a top ten priority, and expect big gains in this area.

Asked about the next wave of business-process automation, the CXOs surveyed indicate that their companies are automating a wide range of functions to improve the overall quality of processes – and, we would add, speed of execution. Few say they have automated processes primarily to replace labor.

When it comes to innovation, we have seen companies harness the power of their workforce’s ideas and insights through digital social collaboration solutions to generate very real bottom line results.

Who’s leading the charge?
Senior management sponsorship and organizational alignment are the biggest contributing factors cited for successful digital transformation. Across the C-suite, larger shares of respondents report that senior executives are now supporting and becoming involved in digital initiatives. Almost one third said that their CEO personally sponsors these initiatives, with CIOs and CMOs not far behind. Further, almost one third of respondents also report a chief digital officer (CDO) on their companies’ executive team – one more chief to follow.

What’s next?
High expectations and continued investment. Less than a third of executives believe their organization spends the right amount on digital, and many worry about underinvesting in these programs, indicating that companies have a long way to go in accomplishing their digital-business agendas. Further, about 50% say their company is up to one-quarter of the way toward realizing their end-state visions for digital programs.

How do these findings compare to your organization? Unless your company is a digital trailblazer, expect to increase investment and prepare for an exciting journey. What not start by learning more about a digital strategy and roadmap?

The post Why is McKinsey Bullish on Digital? appeared first on TahoeSmart.

item.title: Is Walgreens dropping employee health insurance?
item.dc:creator: Amy Widicus
item.description:
If you’re following the latest Obamacare news, you may have heard the buzz about Walgreens “dropping” employee health insurance. What’s the real

The post Is Walgreens dropping employee health insurance? appeared first on TahoeSmart.
item.content:encoded:
If you’re following the latest Obamacare news, you may have heard the buzz about Walgreens “dropping” employee health insurance. What’s the real story? Walgreens is not discontinuing employee coverage, but moving to a private health insurance exchange. The confusion surrounding these reports can be attributed to consumers (and some journalists) not understanding the difference between state and federally sponsored public exchanges, and private exchanges, such as those offered by Aon Hewitt, Buck Consultants, Mercer, and others.

Private health insurance exchanges enable employers to provide a “defined contribution” amount, giving employees a retail-based shopping experience, as they select from a broader range of products to find the plan that best aligns with their needs. The private exchange provides more choices and greater flexibility than the set of two or three options that employers have traditionally offered. In addition, the marketplace may even include health, dental, vision, life, auto, or homeowner policies. These private exchanges are separate and unrelated to the state and federally run exchanges introduced by the Affordable Care Act.

Public exchanges are focused on individuals who have no employer-based option, or qualify for government subsidies. These tax credits are available to households with incomes at or below 400% of the federal poverty level. Due to these subsidies, the public exchanges may also be a good option for temporary and lower-wage workers.

Walgreens is not the only large corporation looking at the private exchange option. Sears, Darden Restaurants, IBM, and Time Warner have all announced they plan to move some or all of their employees to private exchanges for group health insurance. Recent surveys by Aon Hewitt and Mercer indicate that more than 1 in 4 employers are considering moving to a private exchange in the next 3-5 years.

Unfortunately, employees are very ill-informed about private exchange options. According to an Accenture survey, 83% of consumers are entirely unfamiliar with the private exchange concept. However, once informed, 85% of those surveyed expressed a neutral to positive outlook. Survey respondents liked the choice, flexibility, personalized product selection, and retail shopping feel of the private exchanges, and were willing to share personal information in order to make the experience more personalized.

We know that it is critical to educate all healthcare consumers about the real options available to them. The public’s shocked response to Walgreen’s move to “drop” employee health care, in contrast with the positive reaction of educated consumers once they understand the role of private exchanges, is yet another example of exactly how important.

The post Is Walgreens dropping employee health insurance? appeared first on TahoeSmart.

item.title: Open Enrollment Is Almost Here – Are You Ready?
item.dc:creator: Christine Griffin
item.description:
In just under two weeks, the October 1st, 2013, open enrollment date for 2014 coverage will arrive. Issuers across the country have

The post Open Enrollment Is Almost Here – Are You Ready? appeared first on TahoeSmart.
item.content:encoded:
In just under two weeks, the October 1st, 2013, open enrollment date for 2014 coverage will arrive. Issuers across the country have been preparing, yet risks remain, including recently reported concerns with the stability of the integration between the Federally Facilitated Marketplace (FFM) and participating carriers’ online sales channels. Whether you have chosen to leverage the CMS Direct Issue Enrollment API and/or the FFM Lead Generation model – or will be integrating with a state-specific health insurance marketplace – are you ready with a contingency plan should the launch go less smoothly than planned?

In the event that your October 1st individual open enrollment preparation is not where you’d like it to be, there is still time to come out on top. Most consumers will likely purchase over the coming months. Make sure your members and prospects understand they can count on you.

  • Leverage consumer queries to improve consumer education efforts over the remaining open enrollment months. As part of ongoing efforts to strengthen your consumer education strategy, track and publicly communicate responses to common consumer queries. Start now, and continue as open enrollment progresses.
  • Leverage producer queries to bolster the support available to your broker and agent community. As your producer community reaches out for support, engage them with training to maximize the effectiveness of your unique tools and strategies. Make sure they understand the steps necessary to communicate with you to resolve their concerns and get answers to important consumer questions. Provide training updates based on common concerns.
  • Prepare for cut over for IT integration with your state’s exchange. Define and communicate contingency plans for every possible challenge.
  • Focus on stabilizing your payment redirect integration with your state marketplace(s).
  • Maintain your paper application, products, and rate approval as a priority. Your paper application process is the ultimate fall back, should you experience roadblocks with the launch of your online sales solutions. Verify that your paper submission process is clearly communicated and fully ready to support consumer and producer submissions.
  • Validate call center readiness. Staff your call center for an increase in call volume and make sure call center staff are comfortable with the steps for using your sales tools most effectively. If your market includes a segment of speakers most comfortable communicating in a language other than English, make sure staff is available to meet their needs.

Time spent planning for contingencies may be the edge needed to trump your competition in the coming months. Building consumer trust through transparency and clear communication to meet consumer needs may supersede “day one readiness” in the long run.

The post Open Enrollment Is Almost Here – Are You Ready? appeared first on TahoeSmart.

item.title: SharePoint Governance, Training & Communication for Better Enterprise Collaboration
item.dc:creator: David Sidwell
item.description:
Few people question the value of Governance, Training, and Communication for SharePoint and Enterprise Collaboration programs. In fact, according to a recent

The post SharePoint Governance, Training & Communication for Better Enterprise Collaboration appeared first on TahoeSmart.
item.content:encoded:
Few people question the value of Governance, Training, and Communication for SharePoint and Enterprise Collaboration programs. In fact, according to a recent Axceler survey, over 67% of respondents said SharePoint governance was very or extremely important. However, nearly half said governance was “not very” or “not at all” defined within their organization. Likewise, an AIIM survey found that 57% of large organizations report that SharePoint is not meeting their security/compliance requirements – a direct reflection on governance.

Is Governance a Dirty Word?
Governance is the first topic we discuss when starting an Enterprise Collaboration Roadmap, and the foundation of a good strategy. I often tell clients that a lack of governance won’t cause trouble at launch or even 6 months down the road. However at 12+ months, the lack of a solid governance plan will lead to problems that can suffocate your collaboration initiative.

In some organizations, governance has a bad reputation, with numerous failed attempts at governance burned into employees’ minds. Your organization needs to get past this and develop the appropriate governance group and plan to effectively drive your collaboration environments.

Some of the questions we ask about governance include:

  • How does the organization feel about governance?
  • Does your organization have a vision for SharePoint and your collaboration platforms?
  • Is a Governance Plan in place? What does it cover?
  • Who oversees and maintains the plan?

Governance should never inhibit the growth of your collaboration environment. Rather, it should ensure that it can grow in a structured manner that continues to serve the organization.

Training – Will they figure it out?
Given that it impacts adoption, compliance, and security, we ask several questions about training. We need to understand if users are receiving the training necessary to use SharePoint and other collaboration platforms effectively and efficiently.

  • What type of training is available to SharePoint users?
  • Is there different training for different roles? What training is required for each role?
  • How is training delivered? Is it available at the point of use?
  • Do users feel like they know how to use the tool/platform?

Training needs are different based on the role a user fills within the organization. Groups like General Users, Power Users, Developers, and Administrators each need appropriately tailored training plans.

Each of these roles should be reviewed to see what level of training is required, based on the organization’s planned use of enterprise collaboration tools. And training isn’t a one-time activity – it is ongoing as new functionality and capabilities are introduced over time.

I Didn’t Know that was Available
Can a collaboration initiative be successful if no one knows about it? Unlikely. Yet, a communication plan is often a second thought. By helping users understand what changes are coming and why, you can avoid user stress and increase adoption rates. Some questions we like to pursue in this area include:

  • Are there preconceived thoughts about SharePoint or other collaboration platform?
  • What type of communication works best in the organization?
  • Who are the key stakeholders?
  • How do you communicate to all employees?
  • Who should initiate the communication?

Whether you consider training and communications part of governance or separate activities, they are critical factors in a successful Enterprise Collaboration program. Have you given these areas appropriate attention as you begin building your Enterprise Collaboration environment?

Learn more about an Enterprise Collaboration Strategy and Roadmap, or take a closer look at content and search and establishing the right enterprise collaboration technology foundation.

The post SharePoint Governance, Training & Communication for Better Enterprise Collaboration appeared first on TahoeSmart.

item.title: Enterprise Collaboration: Content and Search are Key
item.dc:creator: David Sidwell
item.description:
We’ve been talking lately about Enterprise Collaboration Strategy and Roadmap efforts – what they are and why they are valuable – and

The post Enterprise Collaboration: Content and Search are Key appeared first on TahoeSmart.
item.content:encoded:
We’ve been talking lately about Enterprise Collaboration Strategy and Roadmap efforts – what they are and why they are valuable – and how a good strategy can help you get the right enterprise collaboration technology foundation in place. In this post, we’ll go into more depth on two of the areas covered in an Enterprise Collaboration Strategy and Roadmap: content and search. Content and search are virtually inseparable – content is essentially worthless if users can’t find it, and search has little value if there isn’t useful, tagged content.

Content is Everywhere
According to IDC, the compound annual growth rate of unstructured data in enterprises was 68% from 2008–2012, a number that will only grow. In addition, there are over 4 trillion paper documents in the US alone, with 880 billion added each year[i]. As these documents continue to be digitized, it only complicates the matter.

From an Enterprise Collaboration Strategy perspective, we care not only about the amount of content, but also a wide range of content characteristics. The common “who, what, where, when, how” applies to enterprise content. A sampling of content questions includes:

  • Who creates, consumes, and collaborates on content?
  • What is it? Office docs? CAD files? PDFs? Videos? Social feeds?
  • Where does it come from – internal, external? Where is it getting stored – SharePoint, network drives, thumb drives, cloud services?
  • When is it expired, retained, stamped as a record, destroyed?
  • How is content approved, published, secured, organized, tagged?

Answers to these questions help identify the types of content in your enterprise, and create a foundation for effective future organization, taxonomy and management.

Where is that document? When did I see that Activity Feed post?
Within an enterprise, we commonly find multiple document management systems, network drives, individual computers, social tools, proprietary applications and other content storage areas inside, and outside, the company. With content scattered across the organization, finding information quickly and easily becomes critically important for collaboration to be effective.

AIIM defines enterprise search as “The practice of identifying and enabling specific content across the enterprise to index, search, and display to authorized users.” When looking at search from a collaboration strategy perspective, we need to understand specifics about the content used in collaboration, so we ask questions like:

  • Where is content (such as unstructured content, social content, instant messaging content, etc.) stored?
  • How is it searched today?
  • What metadata is applied to content?
  • Does your organization have an enterprise search strategy or implementation?
  • Is content outside the organization (external collaboration platforms like Dropbox, Box, vendors SharePoint systems, Jive, Chatter) available to search?

Storing and organizing content is inextricably linked with search and retrieval. An enterprise collaboration strategy lays the groundwork for robust, effective content and search.

[i] Coopers and Lybrand

The post Enterprise Collaboration: Content and Search are Key appeared first on TahoeSmart.

item.title: What are Consumers saying about Health Care Reform & Health Insurance?
item.dc:creator: Jeff Bustamante
item.description:
With the October 1st open enrollment date less than a month away, one enormous question remains: what do consumers know about the Patient

The post What are Consumers saying about Health Care Reform & Health Insurance? appeared first on TahoeSmart.
item.content:encoded:
With the October 1st open enrollment date less than a month away, one enormous question remains: what do consumers know about the Patient Protection Affordable Care Act, and are they aware of how the health care law impacts health insurance coverage?

Recently, we conducted a study to help us understand what individual shoppers know about Health Care Reform. Participants included those likely to be impacted by Health Care Reform who also have some of the attributes below:

  • Eligible to receive an Advanced Premium Tax Credit towards the purchase of health insurance for 2014 – based on reported household income level
  • 50% mix of men and women
  • Under age 65
  • Have or previously had an individual or family health insurance policy
  • Decision maker in obtaining a health insurance policy

It was not surprising to learn that all participants had heard something about Health Care Reform, but perceptions varied widely as to how the Affordable Care Act (ACA) would specifically impact them.

  • A majority did not think their own health insurance would be impacted by the ACA, even though many would be eligible for a tax credit subsidy.
  • Few were aware that the individual mandate takes effect on 1/1/2014.
  • Several were under the impression that they could purchase a health insurance plan directly from the federal government.
  • Only one person was aware that health insurance enrollment begins on October 1st.

Participants were asked to define certain ACA related terms, including Exchange, Marketplace, Subsidy, and Tax Credit. Some significant findings:

  • Most did not know what Exchange means as it relates to health insurance.
  • They correctly assumed that a Marketplace is where customers go to buy health insurance, and insurers go to sell it.
  • No one could define a Subsidy, although one participant ventured “Maybe this is where the government can help me pay for health insurance.”
  • A Tax Credit was interpreted as a credit you receive as part of your tax refund for having health insurance. Even considering this answer partially correct, no one in our study identified it as a tax credit to be used towards health insurance premiums.

As open enrollment begins, how will consumers obtain accurate information about the ACA? An April 2013 Kaiser poll showed that nearly half of all Americans are unaware of the impact of the ACA on themselves or their families. The same survey also showed that 40% anticipated looking to family and friends for information about the health care law, versus just 11% polled who would seek ACA information from a health insurer.

Many sources are popping up to inform consumers about the ACA, but this may not sufficiently address the root of the problem – a lack of basic understanding around health insurance. Excluding ACA related verbiage, participants in our focus group were most challenged by industry terminology such as: Copayment, Coinsurance, Deductible, Out-of-Pocket Maximum, and PPO & HMO. Although most were current policyholders – policies that they had purchased themselves – the fundamental concepts of health insurance were somewhat foreign.

How did these consumers shop for health insurance without knowing much about it? It turns out that most chose, or planned to purchase, an insurance policy because of at least one of the reasons listed:

  • “It’s what I had in my previous job.”
  • “Whatever insurance my parents had when I was a kid is what I signed up for.”
  • “I went with the largest insurance company.”
  • “I got the cheapest insurance I could find.”

Only a handful were able to explain how health insurance works, or reported spending time actively comparing benefits covered in addition to price. Unsurprisingly, these were the same individuals who were more knowledgeable about the ACA – but even among this more informed group, there were misconceptions about its impact on their own coverage.

Most participants in our study were college educated and enrolled in a health insurance plan, but in spite of this, found the concept of health insurance complicated. They are certainly not alone – a study published in the September 2013 issue of Journal of Health Economics looked at Americans’ understanding of health insurance and showed that only 14% of those studied were familiar with the terms deductible, copay, coinsurance, and out-of-pocket caps.

We cannot expect consumers to effectively navigate the world of the ACA and health insurance exchanges when most shoppers do not understand the fundamentals. The goal for payers should be to educate prospective customers and policyholders on the basics of health insurance in a simple, engaging way. In doing so, insurers will have a more confident consumer, and can begin building the trusted relationship required to foster customer engagement.

The post What are Consumers saying about Health Care Reform & Health Insurance? appeared first on TahoeSmart.

item.title: Health Care or Healthcare?
item.dc:creator: Amy Widicus
item.description:
When we talk about the Affordable Care Act, trips to the doctor, or the latest in eHealth, are we talking about healthcare

The post Health Care or Healthcare? appeared first on TahoeSmart.
item.content:encoded:
When we talk about the Affordable Care Act, trips to the doctor, or the latest in eHealth, are we talking about healthcare or health care? Reputable publications fall on both sides of the fence, but it appears that the industry is trending toward healthcare. According to Grammarist, healthcare has gained precedence outside of North America; however, both the New York Times and HealthCare.gov adhere to the two word approach. Sometimes, health care appears as a noun (e.g., “Preventative health care is important.”), while healthcare is used as an adjective (e.g., “Find a healthcare professional near you.”)

The hardline English majors among us will likely continue to refer to the ACA as health care reform – after all, you don’t combine child care into two words – but the trend toward a one-word healthcare shows no sign of slowing. As pragmatists will point out, we used to insist on web site as two words. Eventually common usage won over, with the AP Stylebook announcing the change via Twitter – a story you can read on any number of websites.

The post Health Care or Healthcare? appeared first on TahoeSmart.

item.title: Is Facebook a Viable B2B Platform?
item.dc:creator: Vikas Thakral
item.description:
With more than 1 billion users logging on to interact with friends, family, and brands, many B2C companies look to Facebook to

The post Is Facebook a Viable B2B Platform? appeared first on TahoeSmart.
item.content:encoded:
With more than 1 billion users logging on to interact with friends, family, and brands, many B2C companies look to Facebook to engage and acquire customers, leveraging strategies like crowdsourcing and gamification. Capital One and American Express frequently run advertisements promoting customer rewards, and American Express lets consumers link their credit card to a Facebook application providing special offers and discounts based on their “Likes” and interests. Although B2C companies often find success with Facebook, is Facebook a viable B2B platform where companies can engage with other businesses? Opinions vary among social media experts. Let’s take a closer look at the numbers to determine where Facebook ranks among social media outlets in terms of its relative value as a B2B platform.

Facebook, Twitter, and LinkedIn top B2B social media rankings in traffic (i.e. number of site visits), visit-to-lead generation, and conversion rates. Facebook leads the big three in driving B2B traffic with a 54% share, followed by Twitter (32%) and LinkedIn (14%) [i]. Facebook has a huge lead when it comes to exposure and visibility, but how does it perform in generating leads from those visits?

When a business spends time and money in order to attract visitors and gather valuable marketing information (such as contact information), it is known as lead generation. Only 9% of Facebook visits result in lead generation. LinkedIn may have smaller traffic numbers, but they also come in at 9%. The leader of the pack, with 82% of social media leads, is Twitter. Twitter outshines LinkedIn and Facebook 9-to-1, and shows much more promise in terms of B2B engagement [ii]. So while the number of generated leads is important, does it lead to new clients? This is the fundamental question businesses consider when investing time and money into utilizing social media as a B2B platform, which brings us to conversion rates….

Conversion rates are defined differently by audience, industry, marketing channel, customer motivation, etc. In its simplest form, conversion occurs when a consumer or business purchases a product, service, data, or information. Twitter has the highest conversion rate (2.17%) compared to LinkedIn (.80%) and Facebook (.74%) [ii]. Based on this data, if a company chooses to utilize a social media network as a B2B platform, Twitter may be their best option. Many organizations will also make use of other marketing channels such as organic search (1.45%), paid search (1.96%), email (2.89%), referrals (2.04%), or blogs [ii].

Based on the data, Twitter is the clear social media leader for B2B marketing, which brings us back to our original question – is Facebook a viable B2B platform? Yes, it is. While the impact may be smaller, it is possible to successfully reach a business audience through Facebook. Invest time in crafting your marketing strategy, and determine the role that social media – including Facebook – will play in those plans.

Sources:
[i] Optify Inc. & Kuno Creative
[ii] Optify Inc. [B2B Marketing Benchmark Report]

The post Is Facebook a Viable B2B Platform? appeared first on TahoeSmart.

item.title: SharePoint List View Lookup Threshold
item.dc:creator: Mathew Conrad
item.description:
As SharePoint admins, we typically deal with end-users who have gone column crazy on their SharePoint list, causing the “This view cannot

The post SharePoint List View Lookup Threshold appeared first on TahoeSmart.
item.content:encoded:
As SharePoint admins, we typically deal with end-users who have gone column crazy on their SharePoint list, causing the “This view cannot be displayed because the number of lookup and workflow status columns it contains exceeds the threshold (8) enforced by the administrator” error. Beginning with SharePoint 2010, resource throttling was introduced at the web application level to limit the number of items a list view (database query) can process in a single request, as well as to limit the number of lookup columns a single view can utilize at one time.

In this post, we will take a look at the List View Lookup Threshold:

Central Admin > Application Management > Manage Web Applications > General Settings > Resource Throttling

First, let’s look at what Microsoft has to say about this particular threshold:

Each lookup column in a list view causes a join with another table. Each additional lookup column in a view increases the complexity of metadata navigation and list view queries. In addition to standard lookup columns, single-value managed metadata, multiple-value managed metadata, single-value people and group columns, and multiple-value people and group columns count as lookup columns.

So why should we be concerned about the number of lookup columns in a list view? (A hint… PERFORMANCE)

Adding lookup columns to a view does not cause a gradual or linear decrease in performance. The graph below shows the change in throughput as the number of lookup columns in a view increases. As you can see, the change in performance from zero to eight is rather stable, but at 10 lookup columns throughput greatly decreases. This test was performed with the list by using only one row. If a list is row wrapping, then performance degrades faster.

The following column types count against SharePoint’s list view lookup threshold:

  • Standard lookup columns
  • Single-value managed metadata columns
  • Multiple-value managed metadata columns
  • Single-value people and group columns
  • Multiple-value people and group columns

To get a better look at this, we can modify the URL of the list in question to return the list schema in XML format:

http://{YOUR_SITE_URL}/_vti_bin/owssvr.dll?Cmd=Display&List={YOUR_LIST_GUID}&XMLDATA=TRUE

Quick tip: To retrieve the GUID of a SharePoint list, navigate to the list settings page and copy the encoded GUID from the browser address bar. To quickly decode the GUID, visit this free tool.

Looking at the sample list schema below, we can see that the columns mentioned above are designated as lookup columns:

One thing to note is that the “Created By” and “Modified By” columns, both of which are commonly included in list views, count as lookup columns. In addition to these columns, we have found that “Workflow Status” columns also count towards the list view lookup threshold.

Therefore, the complete list of columns that count towards the threshold includes:

  • Standard lookup columns
  • Single-value managed metadata columns
  • Multiple-value managed metadata columns
  • Single-value people and group columns
  • Multiple-value people and group columns
  • OOTB Created By & Modified By columns
  • Workflow Status Columns

Next time you find yourself troubleshooting a list view lookup threshold issue, start with the basics! Verify your threshold setting in Central Admin and understand which columns in your list view are counting towards the threshold.

The post SharePoint List View Lookup Threshold appeared first on TahoeSmart.

item.title: Enterprise Collaboration: the Right Technology Foundation
item.dc:creator: Christopher Brotsos
item.description:
When we work with clients to create an Enterprise Collaboration Strategy and Roadmap, we start by interviewing key stakeholders, talking through topics

The post Enterprise Collaboration: the Right Technology Foundation appeared first on TahoeSmart.
item.content:encoded:
When we work with clients to create an Enterprise Collaboration Strategy and Roadmap, we start by interviewing key stakeholder s, talking through topics such as Governance, User Experience, Infrastructure, Tools, and beyond. Over the next several weeks, we will take a closer look at how we use client insights to develop a comprehensive roadmap. To keep things scoped, we’ll focus on Infrastructure, Tools, and Development in this post.

Infrastructure
Although we take a comprehensive look across current technologies, SharePoint is quickly becoming ubiquitous as an enterprise collaboration platform. As a result, we often view it as the cornerstone solution for collaboration. Our main focus when building a roadmap for Infrastructure is to ensure that the right hardware and software on which SharePoint will run is deployed and configured according to industry best practices.

Many of the clients we work with already use SharePoint. Our interviews and analysis tools will dive into:

  • What version of SharePoint are you running? What CUs/SPs have been installed?
  • What are the topology, resource allocation, and service distribution of your farm(s)?
  • How many users access the environment? Is everyone internal, external, or both?

Following the interview, we will go over in detail the impact (both positive and negative) of your current infrastructure, and the steps required to set you up for success. The roadmap may guide you through changes ranging from CU installations to the creation of a SharePoint infrastructure to host your farm.

Tooling
There are many tools available to help you manage governance, security/permissions, site provisioning, stale content and users, page design, workflow, etc. in SharePoint. We have experience with AvePoint, Metalogix, Acceleratio, Nintex, SharePoint Designer, and more.

  • What tools are currently deployed to manage SharePoint? Who can use them, and what can they do?
  • How are you analyzing and enforcing compliance?
  • What steps do you take to migrate content?

The roadmap will help clearly define the goals of the organization, and we’ll work with you to implement the right tools to help you achieve those goals. There’s also timing and budget to be considered – the roadmap artifacts, and the conversations along the way, are intended to help you define both.

Development
How does your team develop applications for SharePoint? With Content Editor Web Parts, InfoPath, SharePoint Designer, Visual Studio, or all of the above?

Are you using SharePoint 2013 yet? If you have already upgraded, we’ll look into SharePoint Hosted Apps built using Napa Tools. Of course, there are Auto-Hosted Apps deployed to Azure, and maybe your PHP developers are creating Provider-Hosted apps too.

Working in tandem, we will discover the types of applications and the range of developers you have in your organization. We will uncover your enterprise SDLC and how it’s being applied in the SharePoint ecosystem (or often not being applied). Defining a roadmap that helps your developers collaborate is a big win for the enterprise. The roadmap will help you align your development team and get them collaborating to create best-of-breed solutions. The solutions they build will further enhance the collaboration experience across your entire organization.

We’ve helped clients of all sizes define their own roadmap for enterprise collaboration, working together to improve usability, performance, and compliance. In the end, we deliver not only a roadmap but a path to improved adoption and greater return on investment for SharePoint and other technologies in the enterprise.

The post Enterprise Collaboration: the Right Technology Foundation appeared first on TahoeSmart.

item.title: Big Data! Fast Data! Usable Data?
item.dc:creator: Ray Conrad
item.description:
In 1999, Bill Gates published “Business @ the Speed of Thought: Succeeding in the Digital Economy”; fast forward fourteen years and Tahoe

The post Big Data! Fast Data! Usable Data? appeared first on TahoeSmart.
item.content:encoded:
In 1999, Bill Gates published “Business @ the Speed of Thought: Succeeding in the Digital Economy”; fast forward fourteen years and Tahoe Partners is preparing to present at the upcoming Global Directions 2013 Conference, titled “Fast Data for Fast Business: Intelligent Information Management Across the Enterprise”. I couldn’t help but reflect on Mr Gates’ book, Tahoe’s core service offerings and the key messages of our conference presentation.

The premise of Gates’ book is that information flow is the lifeblood of a company, and a ‘digital nervous system’ is required to facilitate this information flow in order to produce a highly effective organization. Today, the technologies are available to optimize the digital nervous system and reap the potential benefits of big data, such as:

  • Providing timely insights into vast amounts of customer-centric data (customer intimacy)
  • Rapidly enabling innovation directly impacting products and services (product leadership)
  • Further optimizing business models and operational processes – (operational excellence)

Global Directions 2013 will focus on the fact that while big is good (especially since the technology is now capable of handling all this data) it’s only half of the story. From a business perspective, it’s much more important that data be “fast”, rather than “big”. That’s where the rubber meets the road.

Tahoe Partners will expand on the ‘fast data for fast business’ discussion, exploring the critical requirements of Usability and Adoption. Organizations have the ability to get the right information, target the right users, and deliver it in a timely (fast) manner, but still struggle to effectively increase end-user adoption. If information isn’t delivered in a simple, usable interface, efficiency is lost, the speed of business critical decisions slows, and opportunities are missed. Research by McKinsey and Gartner has shown that collaborative solutions, when adopted, produce a more productive environment:

  • 77% increased speed to knowledge
  • 28% increase in successful projects
  • 29% reduced time to market
  • 52% increased speed to internal experts
  • 41% increase in employee satisfaction

People adopt technology that they enjoy!

In the digital age, businesses differentiate themselves through information flow, the ability to engage end-users, and to change the way people collaborate. Information work is the norm and deskless workers are commonplace. Have companies recognized and accepted the fact that ‘systems of engagement’ are different than ‘systems of record’? Do they understand that engagement is driven by adoption? That today’s information worker expects that workplace technologies match the power and simplicity of consumer tools?

In order to truly leverage the power of big data, transform it into fast data, and reap the benefits associated with customer intimacy, product leadership and operational excellence, collaborative solutions must drive usability, adoption and engagement. Elements such as aesthetics, interaction, usability, personalization and mobile help to drive a rich user experience, one that maximizes current technologies and puts a wealth of information at users’ fingertips.

Mr. Gates’ predictions about the digital nervous system have come to fruition – the Global Directions 2013 conference is just one of many proof points. What will our presentation add to the conversation? We’ll look at adoption through the lens of strategy, creative design, and technology enablement, and explore our belief that real engagement and collaboration are fostered by deploying solutions that people really want to use.

We hope to see you this September in Washington, D.C.

The post Big Data! Fast Data! Usable Data? appeared first on TahoeSmart.

item.title: Top 5 SharePoint Roadblocks
item.dc:creator: David Sidwell
item.description:
Recently, we’ve delved into some of the common obstacles to effective Enterprise Collaboration. This has surfaced a number of general obstacles that

The post Top 5 SharePoint Roadblocks appeared first on TahoeSmart.
item.content:encoded:
Recently, we’ve delved into some of the common obstacles to effective Enterprise Collaboration. This has surfaced a number of general obstacle s that must be navigated. Given that SharePoint is a popular enabler of enterprise collaboration, we thought it would be worthwhile to elaborate more specifically on the common SharePoint pain points we see across our clients.

We see the 5 roadblocks below as the most common.

F rustrated Users
If your site is difficult to use, it will quickly be abandoned. Inconsistent user interfaces, unintuitive navigation, and confusing site configurations minimize the productivity gains that come with enterprise collaboration. If your users are asking, “How does this help me better do my job?” you may have hit this common stumbling block.

Missed Opportunities
SharePoint is powerful, but it is often deployed with only basic functionality (like simple team sites) and treated as a glorified file sharing system. Consequently, users may attempt to use SharePoint for purposes better handled with another tool, or acquire unnecessary applications to perform functions that SharePoint is well-suited for. Be sure to take an enterprise perspective.

Security and Access
Sensitive content is often exposed to unintended audiences due to poor design and implementation, raising issues of confidentiality and compliance. This risk is even greater when a SharePoint rollout includes a powerful search engine such as Microsoft’s FAST. Search should be speedy and efficient, but if anyone can find anything, it’s time to take a look at your governance plan.

Departmental Silos
Don’t let SharePoint exist in a vacuum. When collaboration tools are focused exclusively on departmental needs, your users miss out on enterprise-wide benefits. If your Sales team loves SharePoint and the rest of your organization barely signs in, they might be working in a departmental silo.

SharePoint Sprawl
Lack of governance can lead to SharePoint ghost towns abandoned by users, or total sprawl and unmanaged growth. Without oversight, you run the risk of losing content, functionality, and development in the wilds of an unregulated SharePoint environment. Control and consistency are key.

If one or more of these pain points sounds familiar, you should consider an Enterprise Collaboration Roadmap. These obstacles can be overcome with the right planning and design.

The post Top 5 SharePoint Roadblocks appeared first on TahoeSmart.

item.title: Health Insurers: Are You Educating Your Customers on New Coverage Options for 2014?
item.dc:creator: Christine Griffin
item.description:
Research has shown has shown many consumers feel confused, worried and helpless when looking for health insurance, citing bad experiences with insurance

The post Health Insurers: Are You Educating Your Customers on New Coverage Options for 2014? appeared first on TahoeSmart.
item.content:encoded:
Research has shown has shown many consumers feel confused, worried and helpless when looking for health insurance, citing bad experiences with insurance costs, coverage and fine print. The good news? Credible communication is a proven remedy. As the October 1st open enrollment date for 2014 individual coverage approaches, are you educating your customers – earning trust and positioning yourself to become an insurer of choice?

Most consumers are open to learning about new 2014 coverage options. Creating a smooth education experience – providing the information consumers need in formats they can readily use – may be what distinguishes one insurer from the next. With our clients, we have seen a focus on exploratory learning experiences through a health reform education website, in-store kiosks, and an online tutorial around shopping on and outside of state exchanges. We have also seen community outreach through educational seminars and moderated social media interaction.

But are creative formats the only success factor in effective consumer education? Quality content can be just as important. Here’s a list of key content considerations. Do your consumer education materials:

  1. Address top consumer concerns?
  2. Share factual and accurate information?
  3. Provide consistent messaging?
  4. Maximize accessibility?

Are you reaching consumers with a message describing new options for coverage and for increasing coverage affordability?
Foremost among reported consumer concerns is affordability for coverage which adequately covers needs. There are indications that nearly 70% of consumers are unaware of new options for coverage in 2014, including benefits which improve affordability and add value. For example:

  • Subsidies for premium reduction and cost-sharing assistance
  • Essential health benefits, inclusive of emergency room care, maternity and newborn care, prescription drugs, preventative and wellness services, and mental health disorder services
  • The provision that insurers cannot refuse coverage for or increase cost due to pre-existing health conditions

Do your education materials report credible facts regarding the Affordable Care Act – and are your materials fresh and interesting?
One way to keep material fresh is to spotlight specific ACA provisions or benefits through a variety of channels – blog articles, social media announcements, email and text messaging campaigns, and/or web or newsletter features.

Are you ensuring consumers are aware of the requirements for consistency and the subsequent benefits they can expect to receive?
Consistency is regulated under the Affordable Care Act – through Summary of Benefits & Coverage and access to a uniform glossary of terms commonly used in health insurance. Leveraging these mandates as a promoted benefit to your consumers can bolster your position as customer-focused and a source of transparent information.

Have you made your educational materials accessible to consumers based on their needs?
Some insurers are opting to provide materials in Spanish as well as English, and in a manner appropriate for the expected reading and education levels of the target population of uninsured. We have also seen a focus on ensuring mobile device compatibility for online tools, to support an anticipated need to reach low-income, uninsured consumers who may have access to a smart phone – with limited access to full web content.

Education can be a cure for confusion and an excellent opportunity to secure the attention and trust of consumers. By reaching out to your current and future clients and educating them on new options for 2014, you can establish yourself as an insurer who is ready to be there for your consumers – before they ever need to rely on your services.

The post Health Insurers: Are You Educating Your Customers on New Coverage Options for 2014? appeared first on TahoeSmart.

item.title: Health Insurance and Innovation: Host an Innovation Session
item.dc:creator: Mukesh Pitroda
item.description:
With reform deadlines looming and guidelines changing almost daily, it’s difficult to set aside time for innovation and out of the box

The post Health Insurance and Innovation: Host an Innovation Session appeared first on TahoeSmart.
item.content:encoded:
With reform deadlines looming and guidelines changing almost daily, it’s difficult to set aside time for innovation and out of the box thinking. However, stepping out of our routines and letting the creative juices flow can be refreshing and bring new insights to daily activities.

As a Health Care Strategy team, we recently took some of our own advice and conducted an internal innovation session. The purpose was simple and straightforward – to take a fresh look at how health insurance companies currently engage customers, asking if we were to build portals from scratch, unfettered, what would it look like?

We called in the full breadth of talent – from visual designers, to user experience specialists, to content experts, to digital strategists (although we did ask the technology gurus to sit this one out). Splitting into groups, each team was tasked with developing an idea from whiteboard to wireframe and presenting their concept to the full group. The final proposals were fascinating. But the teambuilding and the innovation process might have been even more valuable.

Whether it’s due to location or workload, an innovation session is ideal for teams that don’t have the opportunity to interact on a daily basis. Throwing out ideas (no matter how seemingly far-fetched) and discussing them with peers in an open, collaborative environment not only builds camaraderie among employees, but has an energizing effect that they can take back to the workplace.

Does your organization offer opportunities to break from the day to day and think creatively? Tell us about it – we’d love to hear what you are doing.

How did we know that our innovation session was a success? When we broke for the evening, we kept hearing, “when can we do this again?”

Interested in joining our next workshop, or talking innovation? Contact Amy Widicus.

The post Health Insurance and Innovation: Host an Innovation Session appeared first on TahoeSmart.

item.title: Enterprise Collaboration Obstacles: Build It and they Will Come
item.dc:creator: David Sidwell
item.description:
“We have a great enterprise collaboration tool. Why aren’t employees using it?” Sound familiar? You’re not alone – we’ve heard this from

The post Enterprise Collaboration Obstacles: Build It and they Will Come appeared first on TahoeSmart.
item.content:encoded:
“We have a great enterprise collaboration tool. Why aren’t employees using it?” Sound familiar? You’re not alone – we’ve heard this from many clients. They’ve established outstanding websites, tools, and functionality, often at significant cost, but they aren’t being used. Why?

In previous blog posts, we’ve covered the reasons this occurs, including lack of enterprise strategy and integration to work activities, lack of governance, and organizational silos. In addition, a common situation we encounter is a lack of internal communication and marketing surrounding enterprise collaboration initiatives.

BUILD IT AND THEY WILL COME
“If you build it, he will come” worked out well for Kevin Costner in the movie Field of Dreams, but building an enterprise collaboration tool is not enough to ensure its adoption and ongoing use. You have to market the capabilities and benefits to your employees through consistent, timely, and relevant communication. You need to introduce them to new ways to collaborate, show them what’s in it for them, model and incent use of the capabilities, and in some cases even tell them they must use certain pieces.

COMMUNICATION PLAN
One of the best ways to ensure consistent communication about your collaboration initiatives is by creating and following an Enterprise Collaboration communication plan. However, according to recent Microsoft User Experience Research, a majority of people were introduced to SharePoint without any communication plan to drive adoption. Involving Corporate Communications (or the team responsible for internal communications) is critical.

A communication plan is always important, and it is essential if your organization’s previous collaboration efforts have failed, stalled or experienced poor adoption.

We’ve worked with clients on communication plans ranging from pretty standard to completely unique. While the exact plan will vary based on your organization, some common approaches include:

  • Messages from executive sponsors and senior leadership
  • Posters and/or tri-folds in cafeteria or break areas
  • Mentions in company newsletters
  • Digital signage
  • Lunch and learn sessions
  • Collaboration evangelists
  • Inclusion in performance plans
  • Ongoing involvement in enterprise collaboration initiatives
  • Sharing of success stories
  • Giveaways, like water bottles and coffee cups

INVOLVEMENT
One area mentioned above that deserves extra attention is the involvement of employees in collaboration initiatives. Surveys, requirements sessions, informal feedback, user testing, training, and other techniques allow you to build a solution that better meets the needs of the user, and to share the solution with the most influential users. People who are involved make better advocates and increase the amount of grassroots communication.

Since most of us are focused on building great collaboration environments rather than baseball diamonds, make sure you have a strategy and roadmap that will foster adoption and growth through communication and marketing.

The post Enterprise Collaboration Obstacles: Build It and they Will Come appeared first on TahoeSmart.

item.title: Enterprise Collaboration Obstacles: Deskless Workers and BYOD?
item.dc:creator: Ralph Keipert
item.description:
I recently read a blog that defined deskless workers as those who “spend more time on their feet and less time on

The post Enterprise Collaboration Obstacles: Deskless Workers and BYOD? appeared first on TahoeSmart.
item.content:encoded:
I recently read a blog that defined deskless workers as those who “spend more time on their feet and less time on their butts.” And even less time, we can assume, in front of a computer. Are these deskless workers obstacles to effective enterprise collaboration? We often hear that the challenges of bridging technology, access, and BYOD mean that deskless workers cannot fully engage with an enterprise collaboration platform. We disagree.

The first type of deskless worker, task-centric users, are those who are not issued a PC (or any device with a web browser) by their employer. This group might include warehouse staff, field service, drivers, shop floor workers, and sometimes sales representatives. The second type, multi-device users, are typically issued a PC, but frequently leverage technology like smart phones and tablets in addition to their laptop. This group can include executives with busy travel schedules, various forms of knowledge workers, and sometimes sales staff.

Task-centric users have relatively specific needs and typically don’t need every last bell and whistle. Multi-device users may have a wider variety of needs, but also a wider range of devices by which to fulfill them. This lays the foundation for the design challenge.

With a good BYOD policy, the issue is no longer that your workers have no way to access your collaboration environment. The challenge becomes one of tailoring the solution to their needs and device options. You don’t want to do all of the same things on a phone as on a PC, at least not in the same way.

The basics
According to Cisco, deskless workers (at least, the multi-device user) typically need to do the following from their non-PC devices:

  • Communicate in real time throughout the day
  • Easily access experts and tools that allow interactive collaboration
  • Access inventory information, company directories, and more
  • Enter data into forms and participate in workflows
  • Access email, calendaring, and personnel functions around benefits, policy, and procedures
  • Access training information
  • Participate in communities and virtual workspace where teams can interact

The needs of task-centric users are much more specific and often more basic.

Point and click is moving to tap and swipe
The days of hyperlinked text and menu bars are fading fast and being replaced with more touch screen friendly design metaphors. This means you have to design a single enterprise collaboration platform with a responsive user experience tailored to different devices – phone vs. tablet vs. PC – while keeping the experience across devices as consistent as possible.

Responsive design – pick the right flavor
Responsive design can mean anything from automated (but often unsophisticated) reformatting of the user experience based on shrinking screen size to a highly tailored, consistent experience across devices.

The wrong thing to do is attempt to deliver the same exact solution across all three devices. Your PC users might be satisfied, but your tablet and smart phone users will be underwhelmed at best, leading to low adoption. As access through these devices grows in popularity, that leaves an increasing chasm.

In our experience, the answer lies in understanding the different types of users and roles in your organization, their specific needs and the devices they access to fulfill those needs. That plus a good design can deliver a multi-device solution that’s highly adopted and doesn’t try to do too much on an inappropriate device.

Governance and security
The smaller and more personal a device is, the more likely it is to be lost or fall into the wrong hands. Do you hear stories about professionals accidently leaving their laptop behind in a bar? Not so much, but phones? You bet. It’s important to build the right governance and security model. BYOD can further complicate this. What should a user be able to store locally on a device? Can you remotely wipe clean a lost or stolen device? What password protections should be in place across devices? These are all questions that can be addressed with the proper design to prevent the phone’s new “owner” from downloading your entire company directory or sneaking a peek at your latest product designs.

Are deskless workers and BYOD really obstacles to effective collaboration?
No. In fact, we think that deskless workers now have their best opportunity to be connected. Smart phones are ubiquitous, smashing through socio-economic and demographic barriers. Tablets are outselling PCs. These trends are not driven by enterprises, but by consumers. Your field technician probably has an iPad. Your warehouse worker probably has a smart phone.
