With proper design, BYOD becomes an enabler for connecting deskless workers to your enterprise collaboration platform. It all begins with a smart design and roadmap.

The post Enterprise Collaboration Obstacles: Deskless Workers and BYOD? appeared first on TahoeSmart.

item.title: Create an Innovation Program to Stand Out in the Health Insurance Market
item.dc:creator: Mike Davidson
item.description:
In business and in marketing, there are few words more overused than ‘innovation’ – but it has real impact on a company’s

The post Create an Innovation Program to Stand Out in the Health Insurance Market appeared first on TahoeSmart.
item.content:encoded:
In business and in marketing, there are few words more overused than ‘innovation’ – but it has real impact on a company’s ability to remain competitive. Last week we talked about the innovation gap for health insurers, and how smaller players are leveraging technology to develop new consumer tools. This week, we are taking a look at how insurers can develop their own innovation programs.

In the health insurance market, there is a red-hot battle over the evolving digital consumer interface and online enrollment in particular. With an additional 30 million Americans expected to go online this year in search of health insurance, insurers will largely win or lose based on their ability to differentiate themselves within the marketplace. But beyond the key milestones ahead, like any successful product company, health insurers will need to create a culture and methodology for sustained innovation.

As a Creative Director, I help companies reinvent digital experiences and products. Often that means helping brands establish methods for continuous improvement and innovation. Here are some starters for creating your own innovation program:

Culture Is Critical to Invention
Innovation takes courage. As an organization, it means investing in unknown ROI, embracing change, and accepting occasional failure. Individually, it means putting your credibility on the line. Proposing ideas, accepting new ways of thinking, and supporting risk can be difficult. Creating a culture that embodies these qualities doesn’t happen overnight. Like many grassroots movements, it starts with a small, committed group. Build your core team and adopt a digital lifestyle. Momentum begins with conversation – consume, share, and socialize.

Innovation is a Design Process
You’ve formed a multidisciplinary team that brings together varying perspectives and subject-matter expertise. Nice job! Now, what’s your methodology? There is a simple notion at the heart of innovation – translating ideas into something tangible. That means visualization and prototyping. Your process needs to include various prototype formats that cultivate ideas from doodle to user-acceptance testing. The trick is doing it quickly, efficiently and effectively. Visualization is fundamental to invention but it is not a natural talent for most. Few of us learn storyboarding and storytelling in school. Invest in tools, training, and even specialized staff to facilitate and help improve these skills over time.

Inventive Environments
Part of sparking new ideas is breaking the routine and formal structure of our daily work life. You can foster innovation by creating workspaces dedicated to the process of invention. The goal is to break away from the rigid environment of offices, cubicles and conference rooms by creating a space more reminiscent of a laboratory, newsroom, and art studio. Open, modular, environments inspire team members to connect, share, and build. Immersive spaces where walls are papered-over in stimuli and team members meet around café tables set a tone for ‘what-if’ conversations.

Scope and Define Innovation
In the broadest sense, innovation is an holistic approach that considers all the critical aspects of a business – business model, operational process, systems, technology, consumer experience, and beyond. Defining the scope and specific areas of engagement is an important starting point for each project.

Similarly, it’s essential to define your concept value statement, key benefits, and reasons to believe. Approach every concept from the consumer’s perspective: How does the product work? How do I get started? What do I do next? These details are critical to the function and acceptance of your ideas. Focus on crafting key messages, copy points and calls-to-action, and consider adding a part-time copywriter to your team.

There’s always room for improvement, even in how we innovate. We’re continuously on the lookout for new techniques and methods. Dive in and keep experimenting.

The post Create an Innovation Program to Stand Out in the Health Insurance Market appeared first on TahoeSmart.

item.title: SharePoint Online – Developing and Publishing a SharePoint Hosted App
item.dc:creator: Christopher Brotsos
item.description:
In this post, we will take you through the required steps to develop and publish a SharePoint Hosted App in SharePoint Online

The post SharePoint Online – Developing and Publishing a SharePoint Hosted App appeared first on TahoeSmart.
item.content:encoded:
In this post, we will take you through the required steps to develop and publish a SharePoint Hosted App in SharePoint Online using the “Napa” Office 365 Development Tools. The application will be made available in your organization’s private App Catalog (as opposed to the SharePoint App St ore) for you to deploy as appropriate. We’ll follow the steps below:

  1. Create an App Catalog
  2. Create a Developer Site Collection
  3. Install the “Napa” Office 365 Development Tools (Napa Tools)
  4. Develop an App using the Napa Tools
  5. Add your App to the App Catalog and then to a site

These instructions assume that you have sites on which you want to activate your app, and that you have the necessary permissions to perform the activities outlined in this post. Let’s get started!

CREATE AN APP CATALOG
The first step in this process is creating an Application Catalog for your organization.

From the SharePoint admin center, navigate to the “apps” tab and click “App Catalog”. The value “Create a new app catalog site” will be selected by default, leave it as such, and press the “OK” button. Fill out all of the requested information in the “Create App Catalog Site Collection” form and press the “OK” button.

At this point, you will be returned to the “Site Collections” tab in the SharePoint admin center, and your application catalog will begin provisioning. This catalog will host all of the applications that you choose to make available to your organization.

CREATE A DEVELOPER SITE COLLECTION
The next step in the process is to create a developer site collection. The collection’s root web will be where you develop and test your applications before publishing them; in that vein, it will be the site to which you add the Napa Tools.

From the SharePoint admin center “site collections” tab – click New > Private Site Collection. Fill out all of the required fields in the new site collection form – make sure you choose “Developer Site” from the Template Selection UI.

At this point:

  • You have an application catalog to host apps
  • You have a site collection in which developers will create applications

The next step is to install the Napa Tools into your environment.

INSTALL THE NAPA TOOLS
From the SharePoint admin center, go to apps > Purchase Apps. Although it’s greyed out, select “’Napa’ Office 365 Development Tools”. When the purchase screen comes up, press “ADD IT”, and you will receive a confirmation screen that the addition was successful. Click the “Return to site button”.

Now, navigate to the Developer site you created earlier, go to “Site Contents”, choose “add an app”, and select the Napa Tools app. From the modal trust dialog that appears, click“Trust It”. You will be returned to site contents, and in a short time, the Napa Tools will be added. You can now build SharePoint hosted apps (and a few other app types) using the Napa Tools.

With the Napa Tools now installed, you can now move on to developing your App.

DEVELOP AN APP USING THE NAPA TOOLS
From within Site Contents, or from the Developer site home page, choose “Napa” Office 365 Development Tools. This will launch the application UI – select App for SharePoint, name your application, and click “Create”.

You’ll now enter the browser based IDE – “Napa”.

There is a lot to explain about the App’s default pages, scripts, etc., and Microsoft does a great job of that here: http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/sharepoint/fp123577.aspx. We won’t get into all of the details – just note that App.js has a few default methods, and one of those methods will replace the text of the “message” div with a “Hello” message when the page DOM is ready. We won’t make any changes to the code for this exercise; instead, we’ll work with the default source code to walk through the test and deployment process.

Let’s go ahead and publish our app for testing in the development site. On the side task pane of the IDE, click the Publish button. That will bring up the Publish settings window. Leave all of the defaults. Note the message at the top of the window reading, “The package will be published to the App Packages library”. Click “Publish”. When the “Publish successful” text renders, click the “Visit the publish location” link. That’s going to take you to the App Packages library in the development site.

Next, let’s test the application. Return to the home page of your developer site. Assuming you left all of the defaults, you will find the “Apps in Testing” web part on the home page. Click “new app to deploy, and add your new application.

From the “Apps in Testing” web part, click the link to your app. You will be redirected to your app web, and near the upper left hand corner, you’ll find the App.js logic has executed and written the message “Hello [current user]”.

Everything is functioning as expected! Let’s publish the app and make it available on a non-developer site.

ADD YOUR APP TO THE APP CATALOG AND THEN A SITE
If you were to navigate to a team site in your tenancy and click “add an app”, your new application would not be available. You must first add it to your App Catalog.

From your Developer site, download an instance of your app. I do this by clicking the title link in the App Packages library of the developer site, and then “Save” via the Save UI surfaced by my browser.

Now that you have a local copy of your app, navigate to the App Catalog site you created in the very first step of this exercise. Click “Apps for SharePoint”, “+ new app”, and then upload the app using the “Add a document” form.

Press “OK” in the “Add a document form, and then provide any metadata that is important for your organization using the “Apps for SharePoint” data form that subsequently appears. Save the form, and that’s it…your application is now available to sites.

Navigate to a site on which you want to activate this application, click to “Site Contents” followed by “add an app”. Then, filter down to your applications “From Your Organization”. There’s your app – add it to the site by clicking on it, choosing “Trust it”.

You’ll be redirected to the Site Contents window, and after waiting a moment, the application will be available to on your site.

That’s all there is to it. In a few steps, you have created a site that your developers can use to build SharePoint Apps and a means to publish those apps to your organization.

The post SharePoint Online – Developing and Publishing a SharePoint Hosted App appeared first on TahoeSmart.

item.title: SharePoint 2013 Assessment: Uncover the Benefits
item.dc:creator: David Sidwell
item.description:
We’ve covered what’s new and exciting in SharePoint 2013 in this space before, including posts highlighting social, content management, cloud, mobile, search

The post SharePoint 2013 Assessment: Uncover the Benefits appeared first on TahoeSmart.
item.content:encoded:
We’ve covered what’s new and exciting in SharePoint 2013 in this space before, including posts highlighting social, content management, cloud, mobile, search and more. Powerful new features are great, but features alone are not enough. Given that upgrading isn’t painless, the question is: how much benefit will SharePoint 2013 deliver based on the ways you currently use (or could use) SharePoint?

THE BENEFITS OF SHAREPOINT 2013
We have developed a free online tool that allows you to perform a quick but insightful self-assessment to help evaluate the benefits of an upgrade to SharePoint 2013. Rather than investing lots of time researching the details of SharePoint 2013 on your own, or relying on guidance from a 3rd party that may be more interested in the software than your business, the self-assessment offers a high-level view tailored to your organization. Not all enhancements in SharePoint 2013 are created equal. Some capabilities have made huge advances while others are more incremental – evaluating these features against your business priorities is critical.

WHAT IS IMPORTANT TO YOU?
In the self-assessment, we ask you to rate the importance of ten different SharePoint functions, including:

  • Business Intelligence
  • Collaboration
  • Document Management
  • Intranet
  • Mobile
  • Search
  • Social

Keep in mind that it’s not simply about the needs SharePoint fulfills today, but emerging business requirements such as social and mobile. SharePoint 2013 is truly an enterprise collaboration platform, and can do so much more than team sites and simple document management.

ARE YOU ALREADY USING AN OLDER VERSION OF SHAREPOINT?
The older the version you are currently running, the more you stand to gain from an upgrade to SharePoint 2013. Every version has made significant strides from its predecessors, so jumping more than one version has considerable advantages.

If you’re currently relying on other tools to enable some of these needs, how many are you using? How current is the technology? How much does it cost you to maintain and enhance them? Our experience suggests that many companies are spending more than they should to support a fragmented collaboration environment that does not fully support their enterprise needs. SharePoint provides the opportunity to consolidate on a single platform that is a current and future market leader. In most cases, it’s also quite cost effective when compared to the alternatives.

GIVE IT A TRY
Give the SharePoint 2013 Assessment tool a try – it is fast, free and informative. Of course, we’re always available to answer any questions and would be happy to help you interpret any detailed questions about your results.

Take the SharePoint 2013 Self-Assessment now >

The post SharePoint 2013 Assessment: Uncover the Benefits appeared first on TahoeSmart.

item.title: Health Insurance and Innovation: Trendsetters Emerge to Fill the Gaps
item.dc:creator: Mukesh Pitroda
item.description:
The health insurance industry is dominated by large companies that traditionally have been slow to take advantage of new technologies to serve

The post Health Insurance and Innovation: Trendsetters Emerge to Fill the Gaps appeared first on TahoeSmart.
item.content:encoded:
The health insurance industry is dominated by large companies that traditionally have been slow to take advantage of new technologies to serve their members. With a majority of customers enrolling in group plans through their employers, they just didn’t have to. Health Care Reform legislation i s poised to change that. In addition to the previously uninsured individuals who will enter the health insurance market, a significant number of current group customers may switch to a direct market policy. Insurers will need to utilize cutting-edge technologies to compete with established peers and emerging players in the market, and most importantly, to capture an audience whose expectations are shaped by technology-embracing industries such as banking and auto insurance. The bottom line: direct consumers will expect more from health insurance.

Will the health insurance industry rise to the challenge? Technology is changing at a pace that many insurers cannot maintain, at least not in the near term. Health insurance is still a heavy waterfall industry entering very agile times. That said, traditional insurers have demonstrated an increased focus on the Customer Experience, with investments in web-based education and targeted outreach to emerging consumer micro-segments, both cultural and generational.

I predict that we’ll see (even more) small companies enter the industry and carve out niche service areas. They will develop cutting-edge products that bridge the gap between the data and information that insurance companies have in abundance, and the delivery methods that consumers demand. These innovators will engage consumers with transparent, convenient, interactive applications. I recently read about a new individual health insurance company concentrating solely on the young, tech savvy market. CakeHealth bills itself as the Mint of health care, and ZocDoc lets users book a doctor appointment as easily as making a dinner reservation. Tools like these hit major touch points of consumer need – offering real-time information on-demand and free of charge.

Health Care Reform has opened the doors for smaller players to enter the market and make an impact through innovative technologies. I am interested to see how the industry shifts as regulations take effect in October. I expect that large insurers will continue to do what they do best, providing policies to a majority of insured individuals; but also, that we will see many pioneering companies emerge with creative new tools to supplement the user experience.

The post Health Insurance and Innovation: Trendsetters Emerge to Fill the Gaps appeared first on TahoeSmart.

item.title: Health Insurance Consumers: Are You Making It Easy For Them To Stay in 2014?
item.dc:creator: Amy Widicus
item.description:
Rate Shock – it’s on everyone’s mind, and under debate in every media channel. What is going to happen to individual consumers

The post Health Insurance Consumers: Are You Making It Easy For Them To Stay in 2014? appeared first on TahoeSmart.
item.content:encoded:
Rate Shock – it’s on everyone’s mind, and under debate in every media channel. What is going to happen to individual consumers with the evolution of Reform? What are you, as an insurer, doing to make the transition seamless for your individual customers? If the transition to new plans is easy, more members will stay with their current insurer.

Several options are on the table. Some insurers are re-establishing anniversary dates. This allows members to stay on their current policy for a longer period of time (through 2014), maintaining lower premiums and giving insurers more time to migrate members to new Qualified Health Plans. This option is highly dependent on individual State DOI approval. Even if approved, some states will require discontinuing current plans and replacing with an identical benefit plan with a new anniversary date. Other insurers are looking at migrating existing customers to an ACA compliance policy automatically (depending on state DOI approval) or through their shopping experience at the end of 2013. Any type of transition will require extensive member and broker communications through multiple channels.

As you migrate existing users, you’ll want to consider what to use as the basis for migration or recommending a QHP. There are several options, including:

  • Actual value and plan benefits
  • Similar benefits to member’s current plan
  • Similar cost to member’s current plan
  • An additional low-cost option with the same network as the member’s current plan

Within the migration plan, it will also be critical to identify those members who may now be tax-credit eligible, and to integrate this seamlessly into the member experience. Consider adding a tax credit estimator directly within the process, rather than forcing them through a separate experience.

Make sure you are tackling the most pressing questions. How are you planning to migrate your existing customers? Do you know the regulations in your state? How will this be communicated to your members? Whatever the strategy, it is critical to define a seamless transition for the consumer through the online member portal as well as aligned communications through digital and direct channels. Helping consumers understand their options, the benefits of your approach, what any changes mean to them, and giving them the ability to seamlessly re-enroll will be keys to success.

The post Health Insurance Consumers: Are You Making It Easy For Them To Stay in 2014? appeared first on TahoeSmart.

item.title: Enterprise Collaboration Obstacles: Ungoverned Confusion
item.dc:creator: Ralph Keipert
item.description:
Some organizations have taken an organic approach to enabling collaboration within the enterprise by making collaboration tools available – but often without

The post Enterprise Collaboration Obstacles: Ungoverned Confusion appeared first on TahoeSmart.
item.content:encoded:
Some organizations have taken an organic approach to enabling collaboration within the enterprise by making collaboration tools available – but often without considering best practices. At face value, putting departmental users in control seems like a reasonable way to facilitate adoption, howe ver, this approach lacks good governance and leads to significant challenges in achieving long term enterprise adoption. When clients turn to us to help implement a governance strategy, it’s often because they are experiencing one or more common challenges related to weak governance: inconsistency across the organization, compliance issues due to lax security policies, or poor system performance.

A recent survey published in eWeek found that 51% of respondents admitted their organization had not implemented any form of enterprise collaboration governance strategy. Of those with a governance plan in place, only a third said there was a general awareness of the governance plan or an ongoing management strategy. This shows a dramatic gap between the 67% of respondents who said governance was extremely or very important to their business.

Lack of consistency leads to confusion
Without effective governance, the only constant is that everyone will do things differently. Best practices are not applied, as users are left to their own devices. Training is nearly impossible because there are too many variations across users and departments. Enterprise content management and enterprise search become unachievable, as content is organized with a department focus rather than an enterprise focus. Collaboration implementations can quickly turn into a “wild west”, with hundreds or thousands of sites, many of them with outdated, unused content and no ownership. The worst possible outcome is a confused and frustrated user giving up. Governance doesn’t have to be hard, nor does it need to be confining. Doing some basic things consistently and according to best practices can pay huge dividends in downstream adoption and realization of enterprise benefits.

Confidential information made public
One of the first things an auditor will do is perform an internal search on the word “confidential”. The results can be surprising. Documents and content that are presumably secure are suddenly available to a much wider audience. The root of this issue lies in ineffective governance. Setting permissions and securing content are key elements of a strong governance plan. Once a problem of this nature is uncovered, the reaction is often to implement an overly restrictive policy, impeding users’ ability to find (non-confidential) information. Over time, an overly restrictive policy can lead to lower adoption as users perceive key information to be unavailable or too hard to access. Of course, the consequences associated with no policy or an overly liberal policy could be far worse. Effective governance strikes the right balance.

System performance is hobbled
Without governance on organizing and storing information, we’ve seen mistakes made that have brought performance of an enterprise collaboration system to its knees. Further, the manpower needed to support and maintain ungoverned and uncontrolled systems grows disproportionately to the size of the environment. If content and sites are properly deployed in concert with an overall governance plan, performance issues can be avoided. The last thing anyone wants is a slow performing system.

How can I avoid the problems that come with a lack of governance?
An enterprise collaboration roadmap provides the start of a governance plan. A good governance plan facilitates three key drivers of adoption: consistency, appropriate information access, and an architecture that delivers speedy system response times. Here’s a great blog post that covers the Enterprise Collaboration Roadmap in more detail.

The post Enterprise Collaboration Obstacles: Ungoverned Confusion appeared first on TahoeSmart.

item.title: Health Insurers sound more like Marketers (and that’s a good thing)
item.dc:creator: Mukesh Pitroda
item.description:
At this year’s AHIP Institute conference, there were two topics that seemed to overshadow all others: the customer experience and the Health

The post Health Insurers sound more like Marketers (and that’s a good thing) appeared first on TahoeSmart.
item.content:encoded:
At this year’s AHIP Institute conference, there were two topics that seemed to overshadow all others: the customer experience and the Health Insurance Exchange. What these topics share is an emphasis on the individual customer and a shift away from B2B to a B2C focus. Health insurers understand that exchanges offer an opportunity to increase their customer base by capturing a portion of the newly insured. However, to attract those consumers, companies need to create an emotional bond with the customer.

Speakers at AHIP provided some insight into how to build that bond. It’s essential to start from within – and that means creating the right culture and hiring the right people. Today’s B2C organization has to practice what it preaches, creating an open culture based on core values, with employees who represent those principles.

In addition, insurers need to recognize what consumers go through – if we don’t understand our customers, how will we be able to connect with them? We hear buzzwords like “big data” all the time, and it’s true that current technology offers a treasure trove of information. But it’s essential to look beyond demographic data and really understand the consumer in order to provide an experience that is meaningful to them. It means walking in their shoes, understanding the highlights and the pain points-only then can we create an experience that they relate to.

According to some of the statistics shown at AHIP, 70-80 percent of those currently uninsured do not know how what their options will be in 2014. Providing the right educational tools for consumers – not only about your products, but about health insurance in general – is part of creating a world-class customer experience. Many shoppers will be purchasing health for the first time. Engage these customers through communities and microsites, and empower them to self-service and easily provide feedback.

To be successful in this new landscape of individual consumers, forward-thinking insurers realize they need to focus on key aspects that have made other B2C companies successful. The approach isn’t new, but it’s new to the insurance industry, and those who are able to become more customer-focused will see the greatest benefit.

The post Health Insurers sound more like Marketers (and that’s a good thing) appeared first on TahoeSmart.

item.title: Enterprise Collaboration Obstacles: Breaking Down Organizational Silos
item.dc:creator: Ralph Keipert
item.description:
We’ve talked before about low adoption as a killer of effective collaboration, but organizational silos can be a huge obstacle as well. We

The post Enterprise Collaboration Obstacles: Breaking Down Organizational Silos appeared first on TahoeSmart.
item.content:encoded:
We’ve talked before about low adoption as a killer of effective collaboration, but organizational silos can be a huge obstacle as well. We have seen cases where collaboration tools are used with reasonable effectiveness within departments, but the broader enterprise benefits go unrealized. Why is this?

The problem with departmental adoption only.
Content and knowledge are generally not only useful and relevant to one specific department. It may not be valuable to everyone within an organization, but it’s rarely of importance to just one group. Further, many business processes have stakeholders or contributors across departments. Intentionally or not, limiting access to knowledge and content and transparency to enterprise business processes will reinforce departmental silos and impede collaboration at an enterprise level. What’s worse, departments often pick their own tools and platforms. If product development is using Yammer and your sales force is using Chatter, you can be assured that there’s not much electronic collaboration happening – not to mention the agony of watching your ongoing maintenance and support costs going through the roof.

A recent McKinsey study, “The rise of the networked enterprise: Web 2.0 finds its payday” concluded that “companies using the Web intensively gain greater market share and higher margins.” What executive wouldn’t get excited about that? Further, McKinsey states, “A new class of company is emerging – one that uses collaborative Web 2.0 technologies intensively to connect the internal efforts of employees and to extend the organization’s reach to customers, partners, and suppliers. We call this new kind of company the networked enterprise.”

The networked enterprise requires an enterprise view of content, processes and use of collaboration tools.

Collaboration with the enterprise in mind.
Content. Two things that spring to the surface in a discussion of content are taxonomy and permissions. Once content is created and stored, the simple adage applies that information is only useful if it can be easily found. This is why search has become such a powerful tool. Free form text search has replaced almost every other historical method of retrieving electronic content. We have Google to thank for that. If you expect your internal customers to find information that will make them more productive at work in ways that are not clearly and accurately defined (taxonomy), it won’t be easy, and they’ll continue to use whatever less effective method they apply today. Of course, who can view and modify content is another important determination. Search can be powerful. Without the right restrictions, it could be too powerful.

Process/Workflow. Since many business processes transcend organizational boundaries, proper transparency across departments is critical. Many transactional processes centered on structured data have already been automated by ERP systems and the like, and provide transparency to those that need it. In our experience, what are often not automated are collaborative processes that involve unstructured content (documents, designs, etc.). Think of activities like product or project management – any process currently managed by spreadsheets and email. We’ve found huge opportunities to increase speed of execution to results and reduction in errors in these scenarios. In fact, one client was able to reduce turnaround time for transportation costing by 90%, and cut approval times in half. It’s amazing what’s possible.

Social. Although social business has its roots in consumer social technologies, this isn’t Facebook or Pinterest. Social business is about finding the right experts quickly, fostering communities of people with like interests and skills, improving project communication and execution, and about reducing the amount of email flowing through your organization. Some argue that social is the end of cc: in email. Time will tell, but without an enterprise solution and a common platform for collaboration, organizational silos prevail and the opportunity is squandered.

How can I avoid the trap of organizational silos?
In our experience, collaboration across the enterprise begins with a strongly supported enterprise collaboration strategy and roadmap. Buy-in and involvement across departments is essential. This strategy must set a foundation for content taxonomy built with users and their work activities in mind, along with appropriate permission safeguards. Surfacing opportunities to accelerate collaborative business processes is critical. Here’s a great blog post that discusses the Enterprise Collaboration Roadmap in more detail.

The post Enterprise Collaboration Obstacles: Breaking Down Organizational Silos appeared first on TahoeSmart.

item.title: Measure and Manage: Open Enrollment in the Age of Reform
item.dc:creator: Amy Widicus
item.description:
The countdown to October 1 is on, and the next several months should tell us much about what health insurance will look

The post Measure and Manage: Open Enrollment in the Age of Reform appeared first on TahoeSmart.
item.content:encoded:
The countdown to October 1 is on, and the next several months should tell us much about what health insurance will look like in a post-ACA world. With 30 million new consumers set to begin searching for health insurance, it’s time to rethink your digital strategy to make sure you are meeting the needs of this demographic.

In a recent webinar, we took a closer look at what you should be watching, measuring, and tracking as this new population begins to purchase health insurance. We discussed why measurement is important, shared ideas on how to do it, and learned how the results could help you make real-time decisions in a rapidly changing insurance landscape.

If you’d like information on future Tahoe Partners webinars on topics like Health Care Reform, customer engagement, and more, click here to receive updates. We hope you are able to join us.

The post Measure and Manage: Open Enrollment in the Age of Reform appeared first on TahoeSmart.

item.title: CMS Update: FFM Integration Options Reconsidered… Again!
item.dc:creator: Erin Yamaoka
item.description:
With the latest release of the technical specification document from the Centers for Medicaid & Medicare Services (CMS) on June 18th, we

The post CMS Update: FFM Integration Options Reconsidered… Again! appeared first on TahoeSmart.
item.content:encoded:
With the latest release of the technical specification document from the Centers for Medicaid & Medicare Services (CMS) on June 18th, we seem to have come full circle to our exchange integration assumptions published on May 1st. In that post, we discussed an “Issuer Handoff to the FFE” model as an option for integrating your retail shopping experience with the Federally Facilitated Exchange. We then pointed out in a subsequent post that CMS had yet to release any supporting documentation on this model, as they appeared to be solely focused on what we called the “Fully Integration Shopping Experience”. As of today, not only has CMS released specifications regarding the “Issuer Handoff to the FFE” model, but they’ve given it a name: the Lead Generation API. A month ago it seemed to be a safer play for issuers to switch gears and focus on the Direct Enrollment API, in the event that the Lead Generation API would not be available by October 1st. However, if the documentation released on Tuesday is any indication of the functionality CMS plans to have ready for Open Enrollment this fall, the Lead Generation API is back on the table.

To review, under the Direct Enrollment model, users starting at the issuer website will be redirected the Federally Facilitated Marketplace (FFM) to complete their eligibility determination. Upon completion, users would be redirected back to the issuer site to continue plan shopping and enrollment. This would prevent exposing the shopper to competitor products.

The Lead Generation model is being offered as an alternative to the Direct Enrollment model for issuers that were not prepared to provide Direct Enrollment functions. When the consumer is redirected from the issuer website to the FFM, they will stay on the FFM after completing their eligibility determination to complete shopping and enrollment functions. When the user is redirected, the issuer can send a Plan Results Filter of up to 10 Qualified Healthcare Plan (QHP) IDs by which the FFM will filter plan results. With this filter, the user will only see the source issuer’s products upon initial view of plans. However, the consumer will have the ability to reset the filter if they wish to view all plans available on the FFM.

So we have come full circle and are back to two integration models in which all of the opportunities and benefits we discussed in our original post still stand. Stay tuned for the latest issuer updates on Health Care Reform as we learn more about what to expect on October 1st.

The post CMS Update: FFM Integration Options Reconsidered… Again! appeared first on TahoeSmart.

item.title: Enterprise Collaboration Obstacles: Two Reasons for Poor Adoption
item.dc:creator: Ralph Keipert
item.description:
A common theme I hear when speaking to clients is that, after meaningfully investing in intranets and collaboration tools, they are not

The post Enterprise Collaboration Obstacles: Two Reasons for Poor Adoption appeared first on TahoeSmart.
item.content:encoded:
A common theme I hear when speaking to clients is that, after meaningfully investing in intranets and collaboration tools, they are not effectively adopted. When we dig a little deeper, two typical causes emerge: lack of enterprise strategy, and lack of integration into work activities resulting in low perceived user benefit.

Build it and they will come.
A recent survey by Avanade published in CMS Wire reported that approximately 70 – 90% business users utilize enterprise social networking tools, but feel that most lack true enterprise collaboration capabilities. Further, 82% want more enterprise collaboration capabilities in the future. Here’s the surprise. When asked what tools they primarily use for collaboration, Facebook ranks first at 74%, followed by Twitter, with SharePoint pulling in a distant third at 39%. That presents an interesting conundrum – a high percentage of enterprise users who leverage social technologies want more collaboration capabilities (which Facebook and Twitter do not provide) and somehow SharePoint (which does provide robust collaboration capabilities) ranks third. How can that be?

From my perspective, one root cause is organizations deploying collaboration solutions piecemeal and departmentally, often without an enterprise vision. I’ve seen this lead to a skunkworks environment, where disjointed solutions lead to confusion and low adoption. A worst-case scenario occurs when an IT department tries to deliver enterprise collaboration on its own without a true business sponsor or enterprise strategy. We see this often with SharePoint – launched by IT as a glorified network drive to share documents, it never really progresses from there, despite the tool’s evolution as a true collaboration platform.

It isn’t helping internal customers get their work done.
Unfortunately, little consideration is given to the user or internal customer. Enterprise collaboration is supposed to improve workforce productivity, but if tools are deployed without taking into account users’ work activities and habits, and even further, integrated into them, enterprise collaboration is destined to fail. As one of my colleagues says, people engage with technology they enjoy. In the workplace, most of us seek to get more done faster – employees will not take the time to see how unfriendly, complicated technology can make them more productive. They’ll continue doing what they do today.

The Answer – a user centered roadmap.
In our experience, highly adopted Enterprise 2.0 starts with a user-centered roadmap for enterprise collaboration. Critically, this roadmap uncovers distinct user and usage groups, is built around high value opportunities to improve their work activities, and delivers an enterprise vision. Without that, the best one can hope for is low adoption that evolves slowly and organically around confusing, piecemeal solutions. If this sounds familiar, here’s a great blog post discussing the Enterprise Collaboration Roadmap in more detail.

The post Enterprise Collaboration Obstacles: Two Reasons for Poor Adoption appeared first on TahoeSmart.

item.title: Enterprise Collaboration Strategy and Roadmap
item.dc:creator: David Sidwell
item.description:
Does your company have a vision, strategy and roadmap for Enterprise Collaboration? I ask our clients this question a lot, and the

The post Enterprise Collaboration Strategy and Roadmap appeared first on TahoeSmart.
item.content:encoded:
Does your company have a vision, strategy and roadmap for Enterprise Collaboration? I ask our clients this question a lot, and the answer is often “do I need one?” A comprehensive strategy is a critical component of a successful and highly adopted collaboration program. There are plenty of ho rror stories about collaboration implementations that turned into the Wild West, or went gangbusters out the door but quickly lost the attention and use of employees, partners, suppliers and vendors. An Enterprise Collaboration Strategy puts the foundation in place to help avoid these situations.

For us, the purpose of an Enterprise Collaboration Strategy is to establish a baseline for the current collaboration environment, identify the desired future state of the environment, and document the appropriate initiatives to move towards that desired state.

WHAT WE LOOK AT IN AN ENTERPRISE COLLABORATION STRATEGY
Before you know where you’re going, you have to know where you are. We look across multiple dimensions in assessing the current state and identifying the desired future state, including:

  • Application Usage. How are current tools used for collaboration, and how could they be used?
  • Communication and Change Management. How can we best communicate collaboration opportunities to drive adoption – the cornerstone of success?
  • Content. What types of content are created, shared, and consumed?
  • Development, Maintenance and Support. How are collaborative solutions developed and supported?
  • Governance. What people, processes, and technologies are in place to manage the set-up and growth of the collaboration environment?
  • Infrastructure. What infrastructure is needed to support collaboration goals? Is the current infrastructure adequate for the desired growth?
  • Resources. What type of resources and skills are needed to build and support the collaboration environment?
  • Search. How do people find important content scattered across the organization?
  • Social. Can employees readily share what they are working on, and stay in tune with what others are doing? Are subject matter experts easy to find?
  • Tools. What tools exist to automate the administration and governance of the collaboration environment? What is the appropriate timing for installing these tools?
  • Training. What do users need to know to leverage the capabilities of collaboration tools?
  • Usability and User Experience. How can adoption and usage be maximized by providing a user-centered experience?

HOW WE DO IT
First, we review current sites, tools, infrastructure, processes, and other documentation to get a solid understanding of the content, tools, and processes in use. Armed with this background, we perform individual and group interviews. While it is different for every organization, these generally cover a broad cross-section of the organization, including employees from all levels of the company. In these working sessions we hear what users are doing and what they want to do, and we share possibilities.

In addition to internal interviews, we also leverage industry and practical best practices. These cover everything from governance, to team size and structure, to infrastructure and platform (such as SharePoint) knowledge.

WHAT WE DELIVER
By analyzing and assessing that information, we are able to deliver an Enterprise Collaboration Strategy, with details on:

  • Current state. Outlines findings on current uses of collaboration, as well as the main pain points and associated impacts.
  • Future state. Highlights future uses of collaboration technologies, and identifies tools and applications that may not be needed in the future due to platform consolidation.
  • Roadmap. Details specific activities to move from the current state to the future state. High level timeframes and budget estimates are completed for each activity and priorities are assigned.

With an Enterprise Collaboration Strategy in place, an organization has a solid base to begin executing individual high-priority initiatives. These activities might focus on governance, increasing adoption through an intranet redesign, or creation/upgrade/stabilization of the infrastructure.

The post Enterprise Collaboration Strategy and Roadmap appeared first on TahoeSmart.

item.title: AHIP Institute 2013: A Closer Look at Consumerism, Exchanges, and October 1
item.dc:creator: Amy Widicus
item.description:
AHIP’s Institute 2013 is this week, and we’re gearing up to talk Consumerism, Federally Funded Exchanges, October 1, and beyond. Beyond the

The post AHIP Institute 2013: A Closer Look at Consumerism, Exchanges, and October 1 appeared first on TahoeSmart.
item.content:encoded:
AHIP’s Institute 2013 is this week, and we’re gearing up to talk Consumerism, Federally Funded Exchanges, October 1, and beyond. Beyond the conference, we’re planning to attend the Consumer Experience Forum and are excited to hear what AHIP is saying about key issues, including:

  • Developing innovative strategies to reach first-time consumers
  • Frameworks and supporting tool sets to implement customer-focused strategies
  • Data and informatics needed to support the customer-centric marketplace
  • How to motivate consumers to change behavior and stay engaged

We’ll also be at the Exchange Forum and want to learn more about AHIP’s perspective on the evolving marketplaces, and diverse perspectives on what’s happening at the state and federal level. How are different organizations dealing with the uncertainty of the environment? Can we expect more information on when final decisions and approaches will be defined at the federal level?

Additionally, the entire track around The Nexus of Consumerism, Retail and Health Care: Thriving in a Consumer-Centric Marketplace will be a focus for us. We are looking forward to comparing our own research on the newly insured with the findings John Fiacco, CEO and Co-founder, ConnectedHealth and Joan Kennedy, CP Consumer Health Engagement, Cigna HealthCare present during “The Health Consumer: What do They Know? What Do They Want? What Do They Need?”

Finally, “Disruptive Innovation: New Entrants and Ideas Driving Change” should provide valuable insight from the marketplace with speakers from Wal-Mart and Weight Watchers. We’ll be able to compare their visions with the research and behaviors we’ve seen from other non-traditional players.

Institute 2013 should provide a great opportunity to network and share thoughts on these ever-evolving topics. Please let us know if you’ll be attending – we’d love to compare notes!

The post AHIP Institute 2013: A Closer Look at Consumerism, Exchanges, and October 1 appeared first on TahoeSmart.

item.title: Social and Mobile must be part of ALL Digital Solutions
item.dc:creator: David Sidwell
item.description:
Social and Mobile are two of the biggest topics in collaboration right now. Just witness the recent Gartner Portals, Content and Collaboration

The post Social and Mobile must be part of ALL Digital Solutions appeared first on TahoeSmart.
item.content:encoded:
Social and Mobile are two of the biggest topics in collaboration right now. Just witness the recent Gartner Portals, Content and Collaboration Summit, where two of the four tracks were dedicated to social and mobile. Two additional tracks focusing on user experience and governance had numerous se ssions addressing social and mobile. But perhaps it is time to quit thinking about mobile and social separately and start thinking about them as part of a complete experience for the user.

MOBILE HAS TO BE PART OF A SOLUTION
Many of us have seen the staggering predictio ns about the growth of mobile:

  • In Q1 2013, smartphone shipments were higher than traditional cellphone shipments [i]
  • Tablets are poised to out-ship PCs by the end of 2013 [ii]
  • By 2018, 70% of mobile employees will conduct work on personal smart devices [iii]

With the staggering predictions about increasing mobile use, a comprehensive solution cannot be created without addressing mobile usage and the mobile experience. Mobile should not be below the cut, optional, or even pushed to Phase II. All solutions should include strong consideration for mobile because that is what users demand.

Solution providers should not be proud when they support mobile – they should recognize they are seriously behind the times when their solution isn’t properly mobile enabled.

SOCIAL HERE, SOCIAL THERE, SOCIAL EVERYWHERE
At the Gartner Summit, several of the sessions in the social track focused on how social functionality is now embedded in many applications. Just a few years ago, social capabilities were available only through a handful of specialized providers like Jive, Yammer, and NewsGator. Now it seems that every platform in the enterprise claims some social functionality. CRM, ERP, Document Management, ECM, WCM, and other systems all contain social features. The question is, how does all this social capability impact the user experience? If a user has to go to three, four, or even five separate applications to use dedicated social functions, will the user become frustrated, and will adoption lag? In most cases the answer is yes.

SOCIAL INTEGRATION
Two ways to address the proliferation of social-enabled applications is to integrate and aggregate social information for the user.

Integrating social information means that social functionality is integrated throughout the user experience. A user should not have to go to a specific location or application to be social – it should be woven into all areas. At Tahoe, we often have discussions with clients who are struggling with adoption of either their intranet or social collaboration environment (or both). The problem is often that there are multiple environments competing for users’ attention, with neither one providing the full experience the user desires. Intranets, social collaboration hubs, and business applications need to come together.

SOCIAL AGGREGATION
Aggregating social information is the act of pulling social information from disparate applications into a single interface so it can be sorted, filtered, searched, and generally consumed in the way the user wants to consume it. If the user wants to see only information from one source, they can do that – but it is not forced by having separate interfaces for different sources of social content. NewsGator has moved in the direction of social aggregation in SharePoint with Lookout, and other providers are doing the same.

Mobile and social are everywhere these days. These aren’t trends that will go away – both are pervasive enough that we should quit thinking of them separately and instead think about them being core to all solutions. Are you thinking this way?

[i] International Data Corp.
[ii] Gartner
[iii] Gartner

The post Social and Mobile must be part of ALL Digital Solutions appeared first on TahoeSmart.

item.title: HIX Update: FFE Integration Options Reconsidered
item.dc:creator: Erin Yamaoka
item.description:
In a post earlier this month, we examined two different workflow options to integrate the insurance retail shopping experience with the Federally

The post HIX Update: FFE Integration Options Reconsidered appeared first on TahoeSmart.
item.content:encoded:
In a post earlier this month, we examined two different workflow options to integrate the insurance retail shopping experience with the Federally Facilitated Exchange (FFE). In a Fully Integrated Experience, users would be sent from the Issuer site to the FFE to conduct their eligibility determination. The user would then return to the issuer site to complete shopping and payment – never viewing competing issuers’ plans. We also examined a second scenario, an Issuer Handoff to the FFE which would initially limit the user’s view to display only that issuer’s plans, and allow the user to complete plan selection on the exchange.

Those issuers who hedged their bets on the more costly full integration (and they seem to be in the minority), may have unknowingly saved themselves some exasperation in the sprint to October 1st. Based on the focus of the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) on the Fully Integrated Experience, it seems increasingly unlikely that the FFE will be prepared to offer shop functions by the start of Open Enrollment this fall. This means that some type of Fully Integrated Experience is no longer an expensive “nice-to-have” function, but now an expensive “must-have” experience if insurers want to sell their On-Exchange Portfolio online.

So what happens when a user goes to directly to the FFE? Stay tuned for more updates as CMS and the health insurance market tackle the technical challenges of Health Care Reform.

The post HIX Update: FFE Integration Options Reconsidered appeared first on TahoeSmart.

item.title: Mobile Analytics to Optimize the Customer Experience
item.dc:creator: Matthew Feeley
item.description:
It’s been a few weeks since the Gartner Portals, Content and Collaboration Summit, so I’ve had plenty of time to reflect on

The post Mobile Analytics to Optimize the Customer Experience appeared first on TahoeSmart.
item.content:encoded:
It’s been a few weeks since the Gartner Portals, Content and Collaboration Summit, so I’ve had plenty of time to reflect on what I saw and heard.

Two words… mobile analytics.

At #GartnerPCC, you would have had to really try hard to not hear at least one presenter stress the importance of the mobile user experience – it would not be an exaggeration to say that the majority of presentations I attended had a strong mobile slant.

While the importance of mobile is nothing new, the conference got my wheels turning fast on analytics. What is it that we’re trying to measure? And, does mobile let us measure more?

Mobile App Measurement is Different
A mobile app, by definition, causes some interesting challenges when it comes to measurement. Unlike the web, how do we measure behavior when connectivity isn’t required? Consider numerous phone types, operating systems, and cellular carrier networks, and you have yourself a whole new set of challenges. For this reason, many organizations have found themselves reliant on third-party vendors to provide insights on mobile app adoption and usage.

But, let’s talk about what could be possible.

How’d They Do That?
If I stood on my head in front of my laptop keyboard, no one would be the wiser. But, turn my mobile device to landscape mode… and someone just may. Along with traditional web usage metrics, what does how the person performs the search now tell us? Was it something they enjoyed? Was it something they did quickly while walking down the sidewalk (safely of course)? As long as we’re willing to search, as UX practitioners we now have a richer set of data to analyze and build testable hypothesis. If someone is constantly switching the orientation of their phone, then maybe we did something wrong?

Location, Location, Location
I know, I know… the idea that someone knows where I was when I performed a search does have a little creepiness built in. But, the marketer inside me loves it! Billboards, retail stores, and advertisements at sporting event are all stimuli that drive consumer behavior. Tell me the time and your physical location, and I may be able to tell you what inspired your interaction with us.

Mobile analytics isn’t just something else to measure. The data we can now gather gives us a new perspective on our consumers’ interactions and experiences. It’s now on us to listen.

Like most conferences, the Gartner Portals, Content and Collaboration Summit was three days of PowerPoint slides and vendor trinkets – but it delivered as intended. It got me thinking – and rethinking – about mobile beyond the usual paradigm. We know that providing a great mobile experience is table stakes for attracting and retaining customers – but now I’m imagining the possibilities of information and insight they might offer us in return.

The post Mobile Analytics to Optimize the Customer Experience appeared first on TahoeSmart.

item.title: Authenticating .NET Service Applications against the Google Analytics API
item.dc:creator: Blog Admin
item.description:
Imagine you want to build a SharePoint 2013 application to download Google Analytics data for your company web site. One potential implementation

The post Authenticating .NET Service Applications against the Google Analytics API appeared first on TahoeSmart.
item.content:encoded:
Imagine you want to build a SharePoint 2013 application to download Google Analytics data for your company web site. One potential implementation is a SharePoint 2013 timer job, and one of the first questions you will have to answer is how your application will be authenticated when making calls to Google Analytics API. Of course, you can create a dummy Google account and hardcode its password in your application, but there is a better way to do it: use the public-key-based OAuth with service accounts. In this post, we’ll provide example code to demonstrate the authentication component of the logic, and that will get you started on building your SharePoint 2013 timer job.

OAuth is a very powerful and flexible authentication specification, and therefore is very complex. Fortunately, Google provides a set of APIs to handle all of the boring details. To make it work, generate the API key in the Google API console and enable access to the Analytics API. In the Google API Console create a new Client ID, and make it a Service Account.

The console will produce a private key file and make it available for you to download. Store the file somewhere safe, because it is the only copy of your private key.

Note the email address of the service account generated together with the private key. You will need it later.

IMPORTANT: In the Admin console for your Google Analytics account, grant access to the service email address created above. If you miss this step, Google .Net API will return a “403 Forbidden” error later.

To test the authentication, let’s create a simple console application.

First, download the latest Google .Net API. With that done, create the console application in Visual Studio, and reference the following assemblies from the Google .Net API package:

  • DotNetOpenAuth
  • Google.Apis
  • Google.Apis.Authentication.OAuth2

Now, the best part. The following code creates an object which implements Google’s IAuthenticator interface. We will use this object to add authentication information to all subsequent requests to the Google Analytics API. Note the path to the public key file, the service email address, and the scope we are authenticating to. In this example, we are requesting read-only access to the Analytics data.

private const string SERVICE_ACCOUNT_EMAIL = 
 "xxxx@developer.gserviceaccount.com";
 private const string SERVICE_ACCOUNT_PKCS12_FILE_PATH = 
 @"abc-privatekey.p12";
 
 static IAuthenticator CreateAuthenticator()
 {
 X509Certificate2 certificate = 
 new X509Certificate2(SERVICE_ACCOUNT_PKCS12_FILE_PATH, 
 "notasecret", X509KeyStorageFlags.Exportable);
 
 var provider = 
 new AssertionFlowClient(
 GoogleAuthenticationServer.Description, certificate)
 {
 ServiceAccountId = SERVICE_ACCOUNT_EMAIL,
 Scope = 
 "https://www.googleapis.com/auth/analytics.readonly"
 };
 return new OAuth2Authenticator(
 provider, AssertionFlowClient.GetState);
 }

The following code makes a request to Google Analytics to download some data. The request URL has to contain the API Key you have registered in the Google API console, a Google Analytics Profile ID, and data query parameters. Notice that no user accounts are needed, and how simple it is to use the authenticator to add the “Authorization: Bearer xxxxyyyy” header to the request. All details of OAuth negotiation are completely done behind the scenes!

//create authenticator
 IAuthenticator auth = CreateAuthenticator();
 
 //create simple request
 string requestUrlTemplate =
 "https://www.googleapis.com/analytics/v2.4/data?key={0}&ids=ga:{1}&dimensions=ga:networkLocation&metrics=ga:visits&start-date=2013-04-09&end-date=2013-05-09";
 
 //we have to specify the application ID AIxxxx
 //and profile ID in the request
 string requestUrl = String.Format(requestUrlTemplate, 
 applicationKey, profileID);
 
 //create http request
 HttpWebRequest req = (HttpWebRequest)HttpWebRequest.Create(requestUrl);
 //apply authentication header
 auth.ApplyAuthenticationToRequest(req);
 //send the request and get the response
 HttpWebResponse response = (HttpWebResponse)req.GetResponse();
 
 //read the response XML
 string responseXml;
 using (Stream responseStream = response.GetResponseStream())
 using (StreamReader reader = 
 new StreamReader(responseStream, Encoding.UTF8, true))
 {
 responseXml = reader.ReadToEnd();
 }
 XDocument doc = XDocument.Parse(responseXml);

That’s it for the authentication piece. You can now run your console application and verify that with just a few simple steps, you can authenticate against the Google Analytics API using OAuth. The next step would be to port this code into a SharePoint 2013 timer job and store the data in SharePoint 2013 according to your business requirements.

The post Authenticating .NET Service Applications against the Google Analytics API appeared first on TahoeSmart.

item.title: Gartner Summit: The Difference between Apps and Applications
item.dc:creator: David Sidwell
item.description:
At the recent Gartner Portals, Content and Collaboration Summit, I attended a roundtable discussion titled “Why an App Isn’t an Application”. A

The post Gartner Summit: The Difference between Apps and Applications appeared first on TahoeSmart.
item.content:encoded:
At the recent Gartner Portals, Content and Collaboration Summit, I attended a roundtable discussion titled “Why an App Isn’t an Application”. A dozen participants from various companies and the public sector discussed their current state and future plans for apps and applications. These leaders are responsible for internal systems, as well as customer facing tools and functionality. The first question posed was one that we hear a lot at Tahoe – what is the difference between an App and an Application?

APP vs. APPLICATION IS NOT ABOUT THE DELIVERY MECHANISM
Because of our iPhones, iPads, iPods, Android devices and the iTunes and Google Play stores, we are used to downloading and using apps. Many of us think that Apps are synonymous with phones and tablets, while Applications live on a desktop or laptop. This is not necessarily the case. You can have Apps on a desktop or laptop, and Applications on a tablet or phone. In fact, a few weeks ago we posted a piece on Apps in SharePoint 2013, which allows Apps to run in the desktop or on a mobile device.

APPS PERFORM A SINGLE FUNCTION
So if Apps vs. Applications is not about mobile vs. desktop, then what is the difference? In the roundtable session, we landed on a consensus that an App is designed for a single purpose – one piece of functionality. An Application, on the other hand, may handle a wide variety of functions. The App focuses on doing the one piece of functionality very well and providing an outstanding user experience.

By this definition, google.com is an App. The one function it performs is search, and it provides a highly usable interface for that function. And of course Google’s search app is delivered through desktops, laptops, phones, tablets, and most everything in between. Tools like Salesforce and many internal support programs are Applications, containing a larger number of capabilities packed into a single program.

HOW MANY APPS IS TOO MANY?
After distinguishing Apps from Applications, one of the more interesting topics covered was the idea of having multiple apps, with each doing one thing, instead of a single application that has multiple pieces of functionality. Which is better for the user? One example was a city website providing multiple services to the public, including pothole reporting, water bill payment, news updates, and much more. Would an end user rather have one application for the city, or would they prefer multiple apps – one to report potholes, one to pay their water bill, etc.? How many apps for a single company is too many? Statistics show the average iPhone user having between 40 and 50 apps on their phone – will users want multiple apps from a single company? How will they know which of the organization’s apps provides the functionality they want? All good questions that will take time and user experience testing to figure out.

DOES IT MATTER IF IT IS AN APP OR AN APPLICATION?
In the end, maybe the question is not whether you should be building an App or an Application, but how you can combine the best of both into something your users love. After all, users don’t care if it is an App or an Application by definition – they just want to EASILY accomplish their task, whether reporting a pothole, playing a game, executing a web search, or paying their water bill.

The post Gartner Summit: The Difference between Apps and Applications appeared first on TahoeSmart.

item.title: Duplicate Entries in the dbo.NavNodes Table
item.dc:creator: Mathew Conrad
item.description:
Recently, while supporting a high-traffic SharePoint 2010 Enterprise farm running the December 2012 CU, I came across a bug worth noting. A publishing site

The post Duplicate Entries in the dbo.NavNodes Table appeared first on TahoeSmart.
item.content:encoded:
Recently, while supporting a high-traffic SharePoint 2010 Enterprise farm running the December 2012 CU, I came across a bug worth noting. A publishing site running on the farm started to experience increased page load-times and eventually was unable to render at all, causing a SharePoint Correl ation ID to be generated. With the Correlation ID in hand, I used the light-weight ULS Viewer to take a look at the actual errors.

These entries in the log proved to be crucial in identifying the issue:

Unexpected: Unexpected query execution failure in navigation query….
High: An unexpected error occurred while manipulating the navigational structure of this Web...
Unexpected: Unexpected PortalSiteMapProvider was unable to fetch children for node at URL: /YourSite/YourSubSite….

As indicated in the logs, I knew there was a possible issue with the navigation control of a specific web in my publishing site. A quick search led me to this MSDN SharePoint blog by Joerg Sinemus, describing a bug introduced by the SharePoint 2010 August 2012 CU. The bug erroneously causes duplicate entries in the dbo.NavNodes table of the SharePoint content database, eventually rendering the database unusable.

Armed with that newfound information, I opened up SQL Management Studio and expanded the Tables directory of the content database containing the site identified in the ULS log. Right-clicking the dbo.NavNodes table and selecting the Top 1000 Rows confirmed the issue. Using the Name column of the query results, I was able to quickly identify the problematic publishing page causing the navigation control to fail, as there were several hundred rows with the same entry.

With the URL of the affected site and the name of the problematic publishing page, I was able to use SharePoint Designer to open the site and delete the page – removing the duplicate entries from the table and restoring site performance. The page can then be restored from the Recycle Bin.

Looking ahead to a long-term resolution, Microsoft Support has indicated that the SharePoint 2010 April 2013 CU contains the fix for the duplicate NavNodes issue.

The post Duplicate Entries in the dbo.NavNodes Table appeared first on TahoeSmart.

item.title: SharePoint 2013 Workflows: The Top 5 Improvements
item.dc:creator: David Sidwell
item.description:
At Tahoe, we often hear from clients looking to expand their use of SharePoint from intranets, extranets, and document management, to include

The post SharePoint 2013 Workflows: The Top 5 Improvements appeared first on TahoeSmart.
item.content:encoded:
At Tahoe, we often hear from clients looking to expand their use of SharePoint from intranets, extranets, and document management, to include line of business applications with process automation. With more robust workflows being implemented in SharePoint, Microsoft has introduced major changes in the workflow capabilities of SharePoint 2013 to support this growing need. We’ll take a look at these changes from a business user point of view. For those interested in a more technical perspective, there are numerous technet and msdn articles to quench your workflow thirst.

With every upgrade of SharePoint comes the worry about whether the new release will provide backward compatibility. You can breathe a sigh of relief – SharePoint 2013 provides support for SharePoint 2010 Workflows, and SharePoint 2013 workflows will function as they do in SharePoint 2010 without any changes. In fact, you can continue to build SharePoint 2010 workflows through the new SharePoint Designer.

With that out of the way, let’s look at some of the improvements that will make you want to build SharePoint 2013 workflows to accomplish your business objectives.

SUPPORT FOR LOOPING IN SHAREPOINT DESIGNER
A well-known limitation in previous versions of SharePoint Designer was the inability to create loops. This missing feature was often by itself enough to cause companies to look at workflow providers like Nintex, AgilePoint, and K2, or write complicated workflows in Visual Studio. Now SharePoint Designer-based workflows can loop a specific number of times, or until a specific condition is satisfied. If you are the nesting type, you can even put loops inside of loops. All joking aside, this is a great addition that opens up the types of workflows that can be created with SharePoint Designer.

VISUAL DESIGNER
Until now, SharePoint Designer has always been a text based tool. With SharePoint 2013 comes the introduction of Visual Designer. As with the majority of features discussed here, the Visual Designer can only be used when creating SharePoint 2013 workflows. Additionally, you need Visio 2013 Professional to use this tool. The Visual Designer itself is generally what you would expect – drag and drop of shapes that you then configure as needed. Many users will find this visual approach much easier to use and understand than the traditional text-based view.

STAGES
Stages provide a way to group logical sections of a workflow to reduce complexity. A workflow can contain a single stage or multiple stages depending on its complexity. Each stage holds various actions and concludes with a gate which determines where the workflow should go next. If you have created and modified complex workflows in previous versions of SharePoint Designer, you’ll appreciate this feature.

CALLING WEB SERVICES
Increasingly, SharePoint solutions reach out to other enterprise systems to gather and display data that is important to the user. This data is typically accessed through web services, and SharePoint Designer has added new functionality to support this. A new action called “Call HTTP Web Service” is available in SharePoint Designer to allow web service calls. This is another feature that opens up the power of workflows without requiring a third party tool or custom code.

BETTER SCALABILITY
A workflow is no good if it doesn’t run because the environment can’t scale to handle increasing demands. The entire architecture for workflow processing has been reworked in SharePoint 2013. For example, SharePoint 2013 workflows are no longer hosted by SharePoint; instead, they are hosted by Windows Azure Workflow, which is installed separately from SharePoint 2013. Your SharePoint and Windows Azure Workflow environments work together to execute workflows triggered in SharePoint. The details get technical, but the important point is that workflow scalability is dramatically improved and you can be confident using SharePoint workflows at the enterprise level.

While this doesn’t cover all the improvements to workflows in SharePoint 2013, it gives you a preview of what’s new, and how it can be used to support your business. These changes don’t necessarily eliminate the potential need for third party workflow tools and custom code, but you are now able to accomplish much more before turning to those options.

The post SharePoint 2013 Workflows: The Top 5 Improvements appeared first on TahoeSmart.

item.title: Specifying the Order of Fields in SharePoint List Forms
item.dc:creator: Christopher Brotsos
item.description:
Recently, I was working on a bug to reorder fields in a list form. I was pretty certain that I had successfully

The post Specifying the Order of Fields in SharePoint List Forms appeared first on TahoeSmart.
item.content:encoded:
Recently, I was working on a bug to reorder fields in a list form. I was pretty certain that I had successfully accomplished this by redeploying the content type after changing the order of Field elements in the definition (via update-spsolution). That is, fields appear in list forms in the same order they are specified in the content type definition, and changes to the order will be reflected when the content type is redeployed.

Apparently, I was imagining that content type field order changes can be pushed through the definition after the content type has been deployed. I have listed the solution below, but to save you time, here are some methods that don’t work:

  • As mentioned, reordering the fields in the CT definition Elements.xml
  • Deleting the lists and redeploying
  • Using new GUIDs for the field definition
  • Completely removing/reinstalling all features (and the WSP). This uninstalls the content types, but even that did not work.

Fortunately, we can turn to the MSDN Forums, and a great community of SharePoint Architects and Developers. When neither Bing nor Google returned a good result to my question, the forum suggestion engine returned this little gem.

All the way at the bottom was exactly what I needed (and, yes, I up-voted the post!):

SPContentType ct = web.ContentTypes["myContentType"];
ct.FieldLinks.Reorder(new string[] {"Column1",  "Column2",  "Column3",  "Column4"});
ct.Update(true);

Leverage the FieldLinks.Reorder method in your feature’s OnActivated receiver, and voila!

The post Specifying the Order of Fields in SharePoint List Forms appeared first on TahoeSmart.

item.title: Health Insurance Exchange (HIX): Consider your FFE Integration Options
item.dc:creator: Erin Yamaoka
item.description:
As October draws closer, have you thought through your operational and marketing strategy for subsidy eligible users who come directly to your

The post Health Insurance Exchange (HIX): Consider your FFE Integration Options appeared first on TahoeSmart.
item.content:encoded:
As October draws closer, have you thought through your operational and marketing strategy for subsidy eligible users who come directly to your site? What channels and shopping experiences are you planning to leverage to sell your Qualified Health Plans (QHPs)? If you want to retain some control over users’ ability to view competitor products while shopping your on-exchange plans, the Federally Facilitated Exchange (FFE) is presenting specifications for two levels of integration into your shopping experience. We have put together a review of the Risks and Benefits of each to help you decide which is right for your organization.

Fully Integrated Shopping Experience

In a fully integrated shopping experience, users arriving at your site can shop and enroll in your on-exchange plans without ever being exposed to competitor products. This is achieved through the Direct Enrollment Application Programming Interface exposed by the Federally Facilitated Exchange. Although a significant benefit, it comes with commensurate expense in development work and user experience efforts.

Pro: Subsidy Eligible users who come directly to your site complete enrollment in a QHP without ever being exposed to competitor products.

Con: IRS regulations prohibit access to Federal Tax Information required for the Eligibility Determination – restricting the ability to seamlessly integrate the application and creating an inherently degraded user experience.

Con: The cost associated with developing and testing the secure transfers of the consumer to the FFE and back, and invoking the Web Services exposed by the FFE, is significant.

Issuer Handoff to FFE

A second option has been presented to increase traffic to the exchange, while still providing issuers incentive to redirect customers to a site that also hosts competitor products. In essence, this is a handoff of the subsidy-interested user from the issuer’s site to the exchange. Upon initial display of QHPs, only that issuer’s plans would be presented. This is achieved by passing an identifier in the redirect that tells the exchange which issuer site the user was redirected from, and filters products accordingly. However, users would still have the ability to access competitor plans.

Pro: Drastically reduced cost from the Fully Integrated Shopping Experience.

Con: Subsidy Eligible users who come directly to your site will have access to competitor products once redirected to the Exchange.

So which is right for you? There are many considerations that factor into the cost-benefits analysis of this decision, and each insurer’s marketing strategy will largely determine the approach taken by their organization. In the coming weeks, we’ll be exploring this topic further with a series of posts on exchange integration. Stay tuned to learn more.

The post Health Insurance Exchange (HIX): Consider your FFE Integration Options appeared first on TahoeSmart.

item.title: The Evolving CIO and CMO Relationship
item.dc:creator: Emily Deveau
item.description:
In preparation for this week’s Capitalize on Illinois conference, Tahoe Partners’ CEO Ray Conrad sat down with i.c. stars to talk customer engagement, and

The post The Evolving CIO and CMO Relationship appeared first on TahoeSmart.
item.content:encoded:
In preparation for this week’s Capitalize on Illinois conference, Tahoe Partners’ CEO Ray Conrad sat down with i.c. stars to talk customer engagement, and how it is shaping the relationship between marketing and technology.

“If you accept the fact that the ongoing conversation between a customer and an organization is the driving force behind the success of a company, it becomes clear that marketing and technology have become enablers of one another – mutually dependent for the success of the whole.
