By definition, that elevates the relationship between the CMO and CIO to the level of true partnership.” – Ray Conrad, CEO, Tahoe Partners

Read the full interview here.

This Friday, May 3rd, Ray will join Amy Widicus, Managing Director at Tahoe Partners, and Tanya Mena, Director Web Channel at Health Care Service Corporation, to present a case study titled, “Real World Experiences: The Evolving CIO and CMO Relationship.” Don’t miss this opportunity to hear from Ray, Amy, Tanya, and other Chicago IT leaders – visit i.c. stars to register for Capitalize 2013.

The post The Evolving CIO and CMO Relationship appeared first on TahoeSmart.

item.title: Social and Content Governance at Gartner Portals and Collaboration Summit
item.dc:creator: David Sidwell
item.description:
As we wrote earlier in the week, Tahoe Partners is attending Gartner’s Portals, Content and Collaboration Summit in San Diego next week.

The post Social and Content Governance at Gartner Portals and Collaboration Summit appeared first on TahoeSmart.
item.content:encoded:
As we wrote earlier in the week, Tahoe Partners is attending Gartner’s Portals, Content and Collaboration Summit in San Diego next week. I’ll be heading to sessions from all four tracks, but I intend to focus primarily on two: Social Collaboration and Governing & Exploiting Content.

Since I have written quite a bit about SharePoint 2013 (like social features, search features, mobile features, WCM features, and SharePoint Apps), I’m looking forward to hearing some outside opinions. One session, “SharePoint 2013 – Advancements and Impact on Portals, Content Management, and Collaboration” should provide some interesting insight into whether SharePoint 2013 has really made progress in these key areas.

While I’ve also talked about SharePoint in the Cloud, I haven’t spent much time on the other components of Office 365, including Office Apps. The session “Cloud-Based Office Systems: Google vs. Microsoft” sounds like a prize fight. I doubt any punches will be thrown, but it will be a great way to see how these offerings stack up against each other to meet the needs of business.

I’m also looking forward to stepping outside the Microsoft world to hear more about other collaboration and portal products, successes and strategies. Some of the other sessions I’m attending are listed below.

  • Box, Inc.: The Power of the Cloud: Driving Business Insight and Innovation in the Post PC Era
  • Case Study: Your Next Intranet — Combining Portal & Social Disciplines to Improve Business Processes
  • Workshop: Your Next Version of SharePoint — In the Cloud or Not? (For end-users only.)
  • Yammer: Enterprise Social – The New Cornerstone of Collaboration
  • Citrix : Solving the “Dropbox problem”
  • To the Point: Socially Enabled Business Applications — Finding, Following and Filtering What Matters

If you’re attending the conference and want to catch up on any of these topics, or perhaps something more social, let me know!

The post Social and Content Governance at Gartner Portals and Collaboration Summit appeared first on TahoeSmart.

item.title: User Experience and Mobile at the Gartner Portals and Collaboration Summit
item.dc:creator: Matthew Feeley
item.description:
I won’t deny that a miserable, cold Chicago Spring has me excited to head to San Diego for Gartner’s Portals, Content and

The post User Experience and Mobile at the Gartner Portals and Collaboration Summit appeared first on TahoeSmart.
item.content:encoded:
I won’t deny that a miserable, cold Chicago Spring has me excited to head to San Diego for Gartner’s Portals, Content and Collaboration Summit. But more than the weather, there are a few topics that I look forward to hearing more about.

It is not surprising that many of the sessions offered on the User Experience track center around mobile. This has been of particular interest to me lately, as I recently interviewed call center reps from an insurance company, who told me that up to 40% of calls they take are now from people on mobile devices not at home or in front of a computer. For some reason, this number surprised me, and got me thinking about how much opportunity we have to build better mobile consumer experiences. I’m curious to see if others at #GartnerPCC share my thoughts around how voice and speech recognition need to be part of a truly elegant mobile experience – without sliding backwards into a world of frustrating IVR prompts and defiant virtual agents.

In addition, I’m planning to participate in a workshop on how to review your own website. The concept is basic, but I’m eager to hear different approaches to a fundamental component of what we as UX practitioners do on a regular basis. As a consultant, it’s easy to critique someone else’s work. Give me an application or web portal and I’ll give you recommendations. This process becomes much harder when you are asked to critique something that you are intimately familiar with, something you have an emotional connection to, and something that you think is good.

Finally, here are some other sessions I plan to join. If you will be in attendance, please reach out!

  • The Five Graphs of the Modern Web
  • Roundtable: Why an App Isn’t an Application
  • Workshop: Build Development Communities to Build Better Software
  • Panel: Designing Apps for the Work People Really Do by Using Information They Need
  • How Disruptive Vendors Are Threatening Your Incumbent Vendors

The post User Experience and Mobile at the Gartner Portals and Collaboration Summit appeared first on TahoeSmart.

item.title: SAP to SharePoint: Delivering Business Intelligence Reporting
item.dc:creator: Rob Ulaszek
item.description:
Hu-Friedy is a leading manufacturer of state-of-the-art dental equipment, with a long history of technological innovation. When they launched a new company-wide

The post SAP to SharePoint: Delivering Business Intelligence Reporting appeared first on TahoeSmart.
item.content:encoded:
Hu-Friedy is a leading manufacturer of state-of-the-art dental equipment, with a long history of technological innovation. When they launched a new company-wide SharePoint intranet (HUGO), they saw an opportunity to maximize their investment by adding business intelligence report delivery through Microsoft BI.

They turned to Tahoe to create a solution that could deliver critical information across the organization quickly and in a user-friendly format. Our work at Hu-Friedy drastically increased the breadth and depth of their business intelligence reporting, and eliminated the investment of time and resources, as well as inevitable inaccuracies, inherent to their manual report preparation process.

A mix of custom code and out of the box Microsoft BI functionality, including SharePoint and SQL Server Reporting Services, was the right fit for their reporting needs. We designed and implemented a solution that extracts transactional data from SAP, while SSRS feeds information directly into the SharePoint intranet. Employees are thrilled with the improved functionality and usability, and it can easily be scaled for future growth.

For us, a great measure of client satisfaction is feedback from the end user. We had the opportunity to attend Hu-Friedy’s National Sales meeting to help launch the new reporting system – where it was greeted with a standing ovation by attendees. Instead of relying on spreadsheets and email, they can access current and archived reports on time and on demand. The days of waiting weeks to receive critical information are over. And at Hu-Friedy, they are delighted with the results.

The post SAP to SharePoint: Delivering Business Intelligence Reporting appeared first on TahoeSmart.

item.title: Forrester’s Customer Experience Index: Valuable Insight or Fools’ Gold?
item.dc:creator: Vikas Thakral
item.description:
How do you evaluate the quality of the customer experience you’re providing to your consumers? This critical question is one of the

The post Forrester’s Customer Experience Index: Valuable Insight or Fools’ Gold? appeared first on TahoeSmart.
item.content:encoded:
How do you evaluate the quality of the customer experience you’re providing to your consumers? This critical question is one of the most challenging faced by companies today. It is difficult to determine the correlation between design efforts and key performance indicators that measure return on investment for customer experience initiatives – but we believe that the organization that finds an answer will move to the top of the customer experience food chain.

Every year, Forrester creates a Customer Experience Index (CXi), offering benchmarks to measure customer experience. They look at more than 150 large companies, creating detailed surveys that measure performance on three levels of the customer experience pyramid: doing business with companies that deliver value, are easy to engage with, and are enjoyable to interact with. Forrester develops their own rating scale and algorithm for calculating the performance of each organization, based on consumer responses.

One fascinating trend is that value-based brands such as Courtyard by Marriot, Costco, and Target perform very well. In fact, discount retailer Marshalls scored the top ranking for 2013. Some might attribute this success to the weak economy, but these companies have scored well since Forrester began publishing the CXi. It begs the question, what are value-based brands doing right to achieve an “Excellent” or a “Good” rating year after year?

Other industries are not performing nearly as well, with TV and Internet service providers and health insurance companies filling out the bottom of the index. Health insurance companies averaged a ranking between 49 and 66 points on a 100 point scale – placing them squarely in the “Very Poor” category.

Are these rankings accurate? It’s certainly worth a closer look. Consumer perception can vary greatly by industry. Variables such as customer bias or a lack of diversity in participating consumer segments can impact results, particularly when the survey covers only 150 companies. Further, as we mention above, it is difficult to establish a direct correlation between the impact of specific customer experience design efforts and return on investment – or a bump in CXi rankings.

As such, many organizations may not find the CXi useful – but we tend to disagree. In addition to highlighting the industries and companies who are customer experience pioneers, it gives us insight into why some retailers and hotels excel at providing customers with a better overall experience. We believe that the future is in understanding how value-based brands are improving the customer experience, and applying some of those ideas and techniques to the health insurance industry. As we implement some of these initiatives, health insurance industry CXi scores should improve across the board. Fools’ gold? We think not.

The post Forrester’s Customer Experience Index: Valuable Insight or Fools’ Gold? appeared first on TahoeSmart.

item.title: SharePoint 2013 Apps: Six Reasons You Should Care
item.dc:creator: David Sidwell
item.description:
With the launch of SharePoint 2013, Microsoft introduced the SharePoint App Model – a new way to add functionality to your SharePoint-based

The post SharePoint 2013 Apps: Six Reasons You Should Care appeared first on TahoeSmart.
item.content:encoded:
With the launch of SharePoint 2013, Microsoft introduced the SharePoint App Model – a new way to add functionality to your SharePoint-based sites. There are tons of good articles digging into the App Model, so we’ll cover the highlights here and provide links to more details.

THE BASICS
You can think of apps for SharePoint the same way you think of apps for your iPhone, Android, or Windows Phone. Just like apps for a phone or tablet (such as a game or banking application), apps for SharePoint provide a specific piece of functionality that enhance the capabilities of the SharePoint site in which it is used. You might have an app on your phone that provides weather information; likewise, a SharePoint app can be placed on your intranet to display the weather for the user’s zip code. The image below shows some recently popular SharePoint apps on the Office Store:

APPS vs. WEB PARTS
Just as SharePoint users have become accustomed to talking about web parts, Microsoft has changed the game from web parts to apps. A common question involves the difference between apps and web parts.

From an end user perspective, web parts and apps are similar – they both provide a way to add functionality to a SharePoint-based web site. Once created, they can be leveraged on multiple sites with proper deployment and configuration.

The primary difference between apps and web parts is how they are developed and deployed. Web parts are built to run within SharePoint and are deployed directly to SharePoint Servers. Apps run outside of the SharePoint environment and are simply added to SharePoint sites. One benefit of this is that poorly built apps will not impact your site like poorly built web parts can.

WHAT ARE THE ADVANTAGES OF APPS?
Apps have several distinct advantages. Since apps do not run on a SharePoint server, they will not impact your SharePoint server if they are poorly built. Additionally, adding apps to sites does not complicate the management and maintenance of your SharePoint environment. The app store provides a convenient way for you to purchase applications that have been validated by Microsoft, and an App Catalog (see the description below) is an easy way to share and control functionality across an enterprise. Another benefit is that upgrading a SharePoint environment containing apps should be easier than upgrading a SharePoint environment containing custom code developed by other approaches, since it is easier for your developers to maintain backward compatibility. Finally, your developers can use industry standard technologies, such as HTML, CSS and JavaScript to develop apps and do not need as much detailed knowledge about SharePoint. You can see more advantages broken out by users, administrators and developers in this Microsoft blog.

WHO BUILDS APPS and WHERE ARE THE APPS?
Apps are built by your developers, by consultants/contractors you hire, and by third parties. These apps are stored either on Microsoft’s Office Store or in your organization’s own App Catalog. Just like apps for your phone and tablet, apps on the Office Store are provided by third parties and have costs that vary from free to hundreds of dollars. Your company can create its own App Catalog to store the apps you’ve developed. This gives your users a centralized place to locate approved functionality they can easily add to the SharePoint sites they manage. Apps that are created in one area of your company are now easy to share across the organization.

ON-PREMISES or CLOUD
If you’ve read the previous blog on SharePoint 2013 in the Cloud, you know that Microsoft is pushing SharePoint Online and making sure SharePoint Online capabilities are as robust as those in the on-premises versions. In keeping with this goal, both on-Premises and SharePoint Online environments can take advantage of apps.

ARE APPS THE BEST THING EVER?
No, they are not. While we’ve listed many features and associated advantages, Microsoft still has work to do in this area. For example, apps run in an iFrame on the web page, which can lead to a variety of challenges (such as having an entire SharePoint page gray out when a modal dialog is displayed). And as you might expect, the App Store does not contain many apps at this point. The store is relatively new and third party developers want to see the value in creating apps before they dedicate time to creating them.

We’ve talked about the highlights and this post should give you a basic understanding of the SharePoint App Model – you can learn more in this Microsoft article.

The post SharePoint 2013 Apps: Six Reasons You Should Care appeared first on TahoeSmart.

item.title: SHOP Delays: A Sign of Things to Come?
item.dc:creator: Matthew Feeley
item.description:
Is the delay of the Small Business Health Options Program a sign of things to come? As October approaches and 2,300 pages

The post SHOP Delays: A Sign of Things to Come? appeared first on TahoeSmart.
item.content:encoded:
Is the delay of the Small Business Health Options Program a sign of things to come? As October approaches and 2,300 pages of complex legislation take form, I think we can all expect a few more surprises along the way. The latest news about SHOP confirms that the world of health insurance will probably get more complicated before getting better. Let’s take a closer look at the recent announcement.

The primary reason for the delay distills down to choice. In its current setup, the 33 state exchanges operated fully or in part by the federal government will not have enough plans to generate healthy competition amongst insurers, resulting in higher premiums and fewer options. With that in mind, the decision was made to postpone the program in favor of giving both the employer and employee more choice.

The interesting twist is that, even with the delay, the SHOP program still goes into effect this year, and employers are able to leverage the program if they choose. Another wrinkle in this latest announcement has to do with state-run exchanges, which may enact their own SHOP program within the original deadline. So at the end of the day, it looks like we’ll now have multiple flavors of the Small Business Health Options Program.

Like I said… more complicated before it gets better.

What is now more clear than ever is that having everything ‘figured out’ before October of 2013 is an unrealistic goal for any insurer. The payers that can adapt and react to changes (as it occurs) will be the players that thrive in a post-reform world. Easier said than done for companies that are historically built like majestic rock cliffs, not rolling stones.

We’ll learn more about this announcement on April 22, and only time will tell where we go from there. Stay tuned….

Photo Credit: #96

The post SHOP Delays: A Sign of Things to Come? appeared first on TahoeSmart.

item.title: SharePoint 2013 Web Content Management Features
item.dc:creator: David Sidwell
item.description:
We have talked before about the top Enterprise Content Management features in SharePoint 2013 – but we deliberately skipped Web Content Management

The post SharePoint 2013 Web Content Management Features appeared first on TahoeSmart.
item.content:encoded:
We have talked before about the top Enterprise Content Management features in SharePoint 2013 – but we deliberately skipped Web Content Management (WCM) features in that post, since SharePoint 2013 introduces so many improvements in this area. The top new WCM features in SharePoint 2013 bolster SharePoint’s capabilities for both intranets and public websites. However, not all features are included in each version of SharePoint (Online, Foundation, Standard and Enterprise), so be sure to validate that the features you require are available in your company’s version. Some of the most useful WCM features in SharePoint 2013 include:

AUTHORING IMPROVEMENTS
A web content management system is only as good as the authoring capabilities it provides. Limited features and poor usability frustrate content managers and result in less frequent content updates, hard to read content, and poor adoption by end-users. SharePoint 2013 has improved content authoring in many ways over previous versions of SharePoint.

In SharePoint 2013, content managers can now copy content directly from Microsoft Word and paste it into a SharePoint web part with confidence that it will look good in a browser. Copying and pasting into Notepad was a common practice to remove formatting before copying into SharePoint, because otherwise results in SharePoint would be unpredictable at best. Now content managers can save time and get more accurately formatted content.

SharePoint 2013 also improves features related to adding videos to site pages. The uploading process is improved, as is the thumbnail creation process.

Image renditions also improve authoring capabilities. Simply put, image rendition allows you to display different sized versions of an image on different pages. This means you can easily display thumbnail images on an overview page while showing the full sized image on an article page. Site performance can also improve as large images are not always displayed on the browser.

BRANDING
Many front-end designers are breathing a sigh of relief with the changes SharePoint 2013 introduces in site branding. Now, designers are able to brand SharePoint using the tools they want to create HTML, CSS, and JavaScript (during last year’s SharePoint Conference, Microsoft made a point of using Adobe Dreamweaver to create the HTML/CSS files which were then brought directly into SharePoint). This means designers and front-end developers need to know less about SharePoint and can focus more on their core skills – front-end design and development.

DEVICE TARGETING
Device Targeting, or Device Channels, are a way for you to display the same content differently on various devices such as smartphones, tables, and laptops. Since both intranets and public websites are viewed much more often on mobile devices, this device targeting is valuable for a wide range of sites. Read more about the details on device targeting in our post on Mobile Features of SharePoint 2013 or in this Microsoft article, What’s new for mobile devices in SharePoint 2013.

CONTENT SEARCH WEB PART
We detailed the Content Search Web Part in our post about Top Search Features in SharePoint 2013. This feature is worth mentioning here because it allows for search driven sites, which can improve usability, adoption, and personalization. Any content that SharePoint is indexing can be made available to your intranet or public facing website through this web part.

FRIENDLY URLS
In SharePoint 2013 Microsoft has finally introduced the ability to give pages friendly URLs. This means URLs like http://www.yoursite.com/Pages/product.aspx#/ID=453 and be replaced with URLs like http://www.yoursite.com/products/productA. These URLs are more friendly and usable for your users and for search engines.

SEARCH ENGINE OPTIMIZATION (SEO) FEATURES
In addition to friendly URLs, SharePoint 2013 has introduced other SEO features that used to require code work-arounds. Publishing pages now give you the ability to set several attributes about the page, including:

  • Name
  • Title
  • Browser Title (used in organic search results)
  • Meta Description (sometimes used in organic search results)
  • Keywords
  • Exclude from Internet Search Engines

Besides being directly set for a page, these properties can also be pulled from a Term Set in the Managed Metadata. This provides the ability to dynamically populate these SEO important fields.

CROSS-SITE PUBLISHING
This powerful feature allows you to create and maintain content in one SharePoint site collection and then display it in other site collections, a very efficient way to share content across sites. A couple common scenarios where this feature is beneficial include product catalogs displayed on the internet, knowledge base content shared with partners or suppliers on an extranet, and multi-lingual sites. The following diagram highlights the cross-site publishing capability.

You can learn more about cross-site publishing in this article from Microsoft.

MULTI-LINGUAL SITE SUPPORT
While the variations feature is not new in SharePoint 2013, it is now used exclusively for multi-lingual sites. Using variations allows you to make content available to specific audiences (languages) based on the language setting of their web browser. The relationship between content on the source site and different language sites is tracked to enable the sites to be kept in sync. A new integrated translation service provides content managers the ability to specify automatic (machine performed) or manual translation of content.

This list of the new WCM features in SharePoint 2013 should give you a good idea on the focus Microsoft has put in this area – but remember, not all features are available in all version of SharePoint.

The post SharePoint 2013 Web Content Management Features appeared first on TahoeSmart.

item.title: SharePoint 2013 Collaboration – Self-Service Portal and Approvals
item.dc:creator: Christopher Brotsos
item.description:
Approvals are a big space in the business landscape – sometimes they are simple, and other times they are riddled with complex

The post SharePoint 2013 Collaboration – Self-Service Portal and Approvals appeared first on TahoeSmart.
item.content:encoded:
Approvals are a big space in the business landscape – sometimes they are simple, and other times they are riddled with complex loops and compliance requirements.

We recently uncovered a cumbersome workflow for software installation approvals at one of our clients. Today, the workflow inv olves many manual steps such as phone calls, opening up tickets, and writing e-mails. Even more detrimental to the approval process is that participants are not collaborating effectively; it’s difficult to find out the status of a request, who is working to approve/reject the request, and significant effort is being repeated because information used to evaluate the request (e.g. a master list of already approved software) is not centralized.

Workflow and Collaboration is a big part of what the SharePoint 2013 investment brings to the table. We’re going to utilize a few key SharePoint features to simplify the approval and improve collaboration. The features we’ll use are the List View Web Part, SharePoint Designer Workflows, and the new SharePoint 2013 Script Editor Web Part.

Here’s our high-level, blog friendly, version of the approval in SharePoint. It involves three participants:

  1. An employee requesting software installation
  2. An Enterprise Architect (EA) evaluating the request, and eventually approving or rejecting it
  3. An IT Help Desk member installing software as dictated through approved requests

In a few steps we’ll help our client collaborate by:

  1. Making the master list of approved/rejected software available to everyone
  2. Communicating status of the request to employees
  3. Notifying owners of tasks and due dates
  4. Making it simple for employees to request software

BUILDING THE SOLUTION

List View Web Part

The Software Master List is very simple. It contains details about all software products deployed in the organization, and an ‘Approved’ flag to filter which software is or is not approved.

Employees visiting the site will go to a Software Self Service Page. That page contains a List View Web Part which is the Software Master List filtered for the Active field set to ‘Yes’.

From this page, every employee in the company can find out if the software they’re looking for is already approved, or if they’ll need to request software that is new to the organization.

We’ll get to the “Request Existing” and “Request New” buttons in a bit, but first let’s dive into the workflow and list architecture.

SharePoint Designer Workflows

There are three lists used to facilitate the approval:

  • Software Install Requests – contains all employee requests to install new software that is not approved in the Software Master list.
  • Software Review Requests – contains all employee requests to install new software that is approved in the Software Master list
  • Software Installation Tasks – contains tasks that are associated with Software Install/Review request from employees

We can now visualize the workflow process in the image above in terms of SPD workflows that trigger task assignments and e-mails based on our list items’ create and change events.

Note that the Software Installation Tasks list has a lookup field back to the Software Review and Software Install Requests list, so the EA and IT representatives can easily view the details of the request:

So, what about the Script Editor Web Part (SEWP)? That was used to build the “Request Existing” and “Request New” buttons below the List View Web Part.

Script Editor Web Part

Employees never need to leave the Software Self Service page to create items in the Software Install/Review Requests lists. Instead, the two buttons launch those lists’ new forms in a modal dialog directly from the portal page.

One can do this with just a few lines of code using the SharePoint 2013 Script Editor Web Part (SEWP). Note that you can do this in SharePoint 2010 too. In SP2010, you’d use the Content Editor Web Part (CEWP), but that wasn’t really the core scenario for that web part. It seems Microsoft saw users overloading the CEWP to add script to pages, so now we get a nice clean web part focused on just that scenario – the SEWP. Here’s a screenshot of the part in edit mode and the code:

In short, we were able to boost collaboration using the List View Web Part, a few simple SPD workflows, and some novice code in the SEWP. Some key improvements:

  • The List View Web Part made approved items from the Software Master List available to everybody
  • The SPD workflows automated task assignment, provided visibility into approval status, and improved communication
  • The Script Editor Web Part needed just a few lines of code increase adoption, and ultimately collaboration, by improving the user experience.

The post SharePoint 2013 Collaboration – Self-Service Portal and Approvals appeared first on TahoeSmart.

item.title: SharePoint Best Practices: Conduct your own Risk and Health Assessment
item.dc:creator: Mathew Conrad
item.description:
Tahoe Partners and our client, the United States Army Corps of Engineers, recently participated in a Microsoft Risk and Health Assessment for

The post SharePoint Best Practices: Conduct your own Risk and Health Assessment appeared first on TahoeSmart.
item.content:encoded:
Tahoe Partners and our client, the United States Army Corps of Engineers, recently participated in a Microsoft Risk and Health Assessment for SharePoint server (SPRAP). The SPRAP was developed to provide in-depth analysis of SharePoint Products and Technologies configurations, custom code, and operational procedures, and critically, to uncover areas of potential risk to server stability, or not aligned with Microsoft best practices. We were pleased to receive an extremely positive report from the Microsoft SPRAP Engineer, and thought we would share some of our recommendations for maintaining a high-performing enterprise SharePoint deployment.

All too often we see hastily implemented SharePoint environments that disregard Microsoft Best Practices, lack operational documentation and are performing at a sub-optimal level. How can you mitigate risk and help to ensure your enterprise SharePoint deployment is performing at its best? We’ve cut through the long list of best practices to pull out some key checkpoints you can use to improve the health of your SharePoint environment today:

SharePoint Products and Technologies Configuration
Keep in mind that the hardware requirements published on TechNet for SharePoint Server are the absolute minimums for a healthy running SharePoint implementation. Microsoft offers a guide to properly resource your enterprise SharePoint farm.

SharePoint Products and Technologies Customizations
Most enterprise SharePoint environments have customizations, but not all have verified that their custom code is up to par. Here’s how you can detect and fix issues in your custom code.

Operations
Maintaining a healthy SharePoint environment goes hand in hand with being up to date. Stay current with SharePoint updates and Windows critical updates.

Disaster Recovery
Ensure that your recovery time objective (RTO) can be met – enforce storage governance with Quotas.

Security
Security is one of the most important SharePoint best practices for large enterprise environments, but unfortunately also one of the most ignored. For optimal security, use the least privileged service account model.

Performance
Looking to squeeze every last bit of performance out of your SharePoint environment? Design SQL Server storage for optimal throughput and manageability.

The post SharePoint Best Practices: Conduct your own Risk and Health Assessment appeared first on TahoeSmart.

item.title: Focusing on Customer Experience & Digital Innovation
item.dc:creator: Amy Widicus
item.description:
When we returned from Hatch Digital Forum, we wrote about the significant trends that emerged throughout the conference. What we heard, reiterated

The post Focusing on Customer Experience & Digital Innovation appeared first on TahoeSmart.
item.content:encoded:
When we returned from Hatch Digital Forum, we wrote about the significant trends that emerged throughout the conference. What we heard, reiterated by some outstanding speakers, confirmed what we’ve seen in our work – that health reform, growing consumerism, and increasing mobile access are driving significant change in the health insurance industry. So it was particularly exciting to end the conference by speaking on Customer Experience & Digital Innovation, sharing the story of Health Care Service Corporation’s efforts in creating a best-in-class consumer experience.

We shocked the audience a bit, sharing a study from Bain & Co. showing that, among firms that identified themselves as having a superior customer experience, only 8% actually had customers who agreed. There is no doubt that the health insurance industry is in transition – traditional and non-traditional competitors are getting more aggressive in filling customer experience gaps, and customer experiences are fragmented and disjointed across conventional and digital channels.

Recognizing these challenges, HCSC focused on understanding the consumer and their journey through the customer lifecycle, using People, Process, and Technology to close gaps. Extensive research on the digital consumer told them that customers want education to facilitate the shopping process, and simple, easy to understand tools and content. Guiding the customer through major life changes, such as a job loss, is critical.

One thing we’ve learned is that the engagement model is an evolutionary process. You need to be sure to understand where you are and from there, build a roadmap toward future plans. In other words, make sure you’ve covered the basics before chasing the bright, shiny object of the latest cutting-edge feature. For HCSC, that meant identifying quick wins, and leveraging those demonstrated successes to garner executive support for additional funding. Since beginning this initiative, they have seen measurable results, but are continually looking ahead to improve the customer experience.

For those interested in learning more about Customer Experience and Digital Innovation, we’re pleased to post the contents of our Hatch Digital Forum presentation. Special thanks to co-presenters Tanya Mena from HCSC and Chris Althoff from Invoyent for permission to share. (Please note that confidential materials have been redacted.)

Focusing on Customer Experience & Digital Innovation to Reduce Customer Friction, Improve Sales and Drive Down Cost from TahoePartners

This topic is so important, we’d love to hear what you’re doing in the Customer Experience space and exchange ideas – reach us on Twitter @tahoepartners to connect!

The post Focusing on Customer Experience & Digital Innovation appeared first on TahoeSmart.

item.title: Top Enterprise Content Management Features in SharePoint 2013
item.dc:creator: David Sidwell
item.description:
In this week’s Top SharePoint 2013 Features, we are taking a closer look at Enterprise Content Management. While SharePoint 2010 provided basic

The post Top Enterprise Content Management Features in SharePoint 2013 appeared first on TahoeSmart.
item.content:encoded:
In this week’s Top SharePoint 2013 Features, we are taking a closer look at Enterprise Content Management. While SharePoint 2010 provided basic Enterprise Collaboration Management capabilities, Microsoft has made significant updates in SharePoint 2013. This is an exciting development, as we are seeing more companies consider SharePoint for ECM. In this post, we’ll focus exclusively on ECM, saving Web Content Management (WCM) features for another blog post.

EDISCOVERY and HOLD

eDiscovery and holds are important components in an ECM system, and this is one of the areas where Microsoft made the most changes in SharePoint 2013, starting with a new eDiscovery Center site template used to create a portal for managing discovery cases. SharePoint 2013 also adds in-place holds for both SharePoint sites and Exchange mailboxes. These holds can be placed down to the page and list item level – users can still work with the content while it is on hold because SharePoint captures a read-only copy for compliance officers to access. This is a major improvement that prevents user disruption during legal processes.

If you have a SharePoint environment with multiple farms, you can benefit from the expanded eDiscovery capability that allows queries across multiple SharePoint farms. Again, this covers SharePoint sites as well as Exchange and file shares. And when the legal department needs to gather all discovered content, there is a new export feature available that covers both SharePoint 2013 and Exchange 2013 content. You may have noticed the pattern – Microsoft has made an effort to have eDiscovery functionality cover other storage locations (like Exchange), and not just SharePoint.

Check out this Microsoft article for more details on the eDiscovery features of SharePoint 2013.

SITE-BASED RETENTION
SharePoint 2013 takes the important compliance features available in SharePoint 2010 and makes them available at the site level. This means you have much more granular control of how retention policies are applied, when a project is closed, and how content from the site is expired, including site mailboxes that are associated with sites (see below for more details).

SITE MAILBOXES/TEAM FOLDERS
Site Mailboxes allow you to consolidate content that is located in SharePoint and Exchange. This provides a single location to view and manage content from either of these systems. The lifecycle can be controlled using the site-based retention policies mentioned above.

PARTNER ECOSYSTEM
One of SharePoint’s greatest strengths lies in its partner ecosystem, including implementation partners and software partners, and its ability to integrate with a wide variety of systems. While this applies to many areas of SharePoint, in the ECM world, it means powerful integration between SharePoint and vendors providing industry-leading ECM capabilities. For example, there are many excellent providers of imaging technologies that integrate seamlessly with SharePoint. Additionally, large scale ECM requires extremely robust compliance practices. When SharePoint alone isn’t enough, Microsoft partners like AvePoint have tools to enhance SharePoint’s capabilities. In almost all cases, you can be sure if a specific ECM capability isn’t included in SharePoint out of the box, a partner or third party product has already filled that gap.

Next week we’ll continue reviewing new features in the ECM umbrella by focusing on Web Content Management features.

The post Top Enterprise Content Management Features in SharePoint 2013 appeared first on TahoeSmart.

item.title: Countdown to October – is your digital strategy ready for the newly insured?
item.dc:creator: Amy Widicus
item.description:
Not to sound alarmist but… the newly insured are coming! With open enrollment a few short months away, insurers must be prepared

The post Countdown to October – is your digital strategy ready for the newly insured? appeared first on TahoeSmart.
item.content:encoded:
Not to sound alarmist but… the newly insured are coming! With open enrollment a few short months away, insurers must be prepared for a new individual customer base, one that will have different needs than existing customers. This is significant, especially when considering your digital portfolio. Will your website drive customers to purchase online? Are you providing a delightful user experience that will encourage users to self-service (and help you manage your costs)? Is your mobile strategy aligned with these needs?

According to research from PwC’s Health Research Institute, the newly insured will have several key characteristics:

  • They will be less educated – approximately 86% won’t have a college degree compared to 63% of the current population. Education will be critical to the shopping process – well written, easy to understand content that avoids jargon will help users understand complex insurance terminology and concepts.
  • They will be more diverse in background and language – 25% will be non-white compared to 21%, and 30% will speak a language other than English. Think about offering your website in languages other than English, and addressing subtle language nuances (vs. direct translation). Make sure your site feature a variety of imagery that is inclusive of your entire customer base.
  • They are more likely to be unemployed or underemployed – the newly insured will be less likely (42%) to have a full time job compared to current customers (59%), and will generally earn less. Following a user through job changes will be essential to providing a consistent experience. How will your digital channels help facilitate the employment change process? It should be easy for them to stay with you as they move from group to individual and back and between coverage plans. Keep one consistent member record, and remember their history even as they leave and return. Many will churn between Medicaid and the subsidized exchanges as their income level fluctuates – what type of digital experience will these users have with you?

This is a very high-level look at the newly insured – no doubt we will learn more as October 2013 quickly approaches – but even these differentiators emphasize the need to review your digital strategy. They’re coming… are you ready?

The post Countdown to October – is your digital strategy ready for the newly insured? appeared first on TahoeSmart.

item.title: Lessons (and a Winner!) from Hatch Digital Forum
item.dc:creator: Russ Maloney
item.description:
We’re back from New Orleans, and if you’re like us, you’ve spent the last week thinking through all the great ideas you

The post Lessons (and a Winner!) from Hatch Digital Forum appeared first on TahoeSmart.
item.content:encoded:
We’re back from New Orleans, and if you’re like us, you’ve spent the last week thinking through all the great ideas you brought home from Hatch Digital Forum. Although we were there as a speaker and exhibitor, our ears are always open – especially when it comes to hearing how forward-thinking Blues plans are innovating to engage members and attract customers.

There were a couple trends that we heard loud and clear. First, ‘big data’ is here to stay and many Blues are starting to collect and analyze this information to maximize marketing spend. Second, the health insurers who will win in the post-reform environment are the ones who are building a remarkable end-to-end experience across the customer lifecycle. The coming year offers uncertainty, but it is clear that it also presents much opportunity.

And in that spirit of collaborative learning, we’ll be posting the deck from our talk on “Customer Experience & Digital Innovation to Reduce Customer Friction, Improve Sales and Drive Down Cost” (with special thanks to co-presenters Tanya Mena from HCSC and Chris Althoff from Invoyent for permission to share). Check back next week to take a look….

Finally, if you stopped by our booth at Hatch to spin our prize wheel, you’re either the proud owner of a Magic 8 ball, entered to win an iPad mini, or if you’re lucky, both. We’re happy to announce that the winner of our iPad giveaway is… Sherry Gibbs from Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Kansas City! Congratulations! Sherry, email Russ Maloney and let us know where to send your new iPad.

The post Lessons (and a Winner!) from Hatch Digital Forum appeared first on TahoeSmart.

item.title: Customer Engagement in a Post-Reform World
item.dc:creator: Mukesh Pitroda
item.description:
Customer engagement means many things to different people – some look at it as a strategic customer acquisition and retention process, while

The post Customer Engagement in a Post-Reform World appeared first on TahoeSmart.
item.content:encoded:
Customer engagement means many things to different people – some look at it as a strategic customer acquisition and retention process, while others view it as immersing customers in a brand through online social media. But what does customer engagement mean to the health insurance industry in a post-reform world?

The landscape of who your customers are and how they interact with insurance providers will significantly change when open enrollment for the ACA begins. A larger portion of your customers will be direct market who, based on web and mobile usage patterns, will increasingly come to utilize online tools to purchase insurance and get service. They will expect more than just information, they will expect rich and mature retail and member portal experiences where they can compare products, perform routine tasks, and engage on social platforms.

This makes an online presence with mature customer engagement functionality more critical than ever. You’ll need to offer your customers (and potential customers) robust tools to help them find the answers they are looking for.

On Tuesday, March 19, we will present a webinar, sharing some examples of what we’ve seen work well (and not work) in different areas of health care insurance organizations, and discussing the various levels of social engagement maturity in these areas. Come see how you rank. Tell us what you are working on, and ask questions of us and your peers. We look forward to talking with you!

Register today >

The post Customer Engagement in a Post-Reform World appeared first on TahoeSmart.

item.title: SharePoint 2013 in the Cloud
item.dc:creator: David Sidwell
item.description:
In this week’s installment of our SharePoint Top 5, we are highlighting SharePoint 2013 Online (with a bonus 6th item!). One thing

The post SharePoint 2013 in the Cloud appeared first on TahoeSmart.
item.content:encoded:
In this week’s installment of our SharePoint Top 5, we are highlighting SharePoint 2013 Online (with a bonus 6th item!). One thing you will notice is that many of these features are similar to the top features in the on-premises versions of SharePoint 2013. This is by design – Microsoft is closing the gap in the feature set between online and on-premises SharePoint. These are some of the top features of SharePoint 2013 Online.

SOCIAL FEATURES
In Top 5 SharePoint 2013 Social Features, we covered many of the top social features in SharePoint 2013. That post did not differentiate between online and on-premises social features – and for good reason. Everything mentioned also applies to SharePoint Online – Activity Streams, Microblogging, Yammer, Community Sites, and updated MySites are all part of SharePoint 2013 Online.

COLLABORATING WITH EXTERNAL USERS
Project and Team sites continue to be one of the most common uses for SharePoint. One popular step is to extend these sites to partners, vendors, suppliers, and others outside your company. SharePoint 2013 Online makes collaborating with external users easier than ever. Sharing with external users does not require a license, and you can determine if the user must sign in with a validated account or if you want to provide access through anonymous guest links. Either way, it is easy to provide sharing functionality through SharePoint.

CLOUD APP MODEL
SharePoint 2013 Online leverages the new Cloud App Model, enabling developers to create SharePoint apps. These apps are self-contained modules of functionality that extend the capabilities of a SharePoint website – think apps for your cell phone and tablet. Users browse and download apps from the SharePoint Store or from your organization’s private App Catalog and install them on their SharePoint sites. Administrators control what can be installed, so you don’t sacrifice security or violate governance policies.

SKYDRIVE PRO
SkyDrive Pro is a document storage service that organizations establish and manage, enabling users to synchronize their work documents from SharePoint to the cloud, and to take documents offline when they’re on the go. One reason this is such a powerful feature is that people can now easily access and edit their documents across devices, and files are automatically synchronized with SkyDrive Pro when online. SkyDrive Pro is integrated into SharePoint Online and on-premises – both SharePoint and Office desktop applications (like Word and PowerPoint) can save documents directly to SkyDrive Pro. SkyDrive Pro provides Dropbox-like sharing functionality through SharePoint.

BUSINESS CONNECTIVITY SERVICES
Another important addition to SharePoint 2013 Online is the ability to use Business Connectivity Services (BCS) to bring external data into the SharePoint Online environment. This means you can access and display data from applications inside your company’s firewall (like ERP and CRM systems) on your SharePoint Online site. BCS has been available in on-premises SharePoint, but 2013 is the first release where some of these capabilities are available in the online version. Note that SharePoint Online does not provide all the BCS capabilities of on-premises, but expect Microsoft to keep increasing this online functionality.

ALL THE PERKS OF THE “CLOUD”
This article would not be complete without mentioning an obvious feature of SharePoint 2013 Online – Microsoft hosts and manages the infrastructure. Your SharePoint data is in highly secure, geographically distributed data centers with backup, disaster recovery and experts monitoring the environment. Additionally, Microsoft has promised more aggressive update schedules for SharePoint Online compared to the on-premises version, so you will have earlier access to new features and functionality.

Not all features are available in all SharePoint Online plans, so check out this article on SharePoint Online features across Office 365 Plans for details.

In a future post, we’ll cover what’s missing between SharePoint 2013 Online and SharePoint 2013 on-premises, to help you make an informed decision as to which deployment model is right for your organization.

The post SharePoint 2013 in the Cloud appeared first on TahoeSmart.

item.title: SharePoint 2013 – Mobile Forms and Geolocation
item.dc:creator: Christopher Brotsos
item.description:
Recently, David Sidwell posted a blog on SharePoint’s Top 5 Mobile Features where he highlighted (amongst other great features) the new Geolocation

The post SharePoint 2013 – Mobile Forms and Geolocation appeared first on TahoeSmart.
item.content:encoded:
Recently, David Sidwell posted a blog on SharePoint’s Top 5 Mobile Features where he highlighted (amongst other great features) the new Geolocation field in SharePoint 2013. On the ride into work, I was thinking about a real-world set up that would highlight the feature, and it wasn’t long before I literally drove right into a scenario. In Chicago, potholes are a big nuisance, and because of that the City of Chicago has a Report a Pothole Site. The site allows people to report locations of potholes and post a picture of the pothole as a visual reference, with the idea that City of Chicago employees will address users’ reports by fixing the potholes.

Today, the site is geared towards desktop users: it has a lot of graphics and requires multiple clicks to load the report form (which also launches in a new window). It also requires users to specify the locations of potholes “manually” instead of taking advantage of available geolocation Web APIs – this results in reduced accuracy. Tahoe is designing a SharePoint based mobile form to replace the existing Report a Pothole form. We’ll enhance the experience for mobile by:

  • Using JavaScript’s geolocation API to simplify the effort to report the pothole’s location and improve accuracy
  • Using SharePoint’s geolocation field to visually render the exact location of the pothole through Bing maps
  • Making the form lightweight with only the essential input fields

And who knows, maybe this example will be so good that the City of Chicago will ask us to build this for real!

We’re going to need to read images from users’ phones, so a script-only solution won’t suffice. As such, we have two solid options for the project type: a SharePoint 2013 Provider Hosted App or a SharePoint 2013 solution. Discussing the first project model is a blog topic unto itself, so we’ll keep this straightforward by using a SharePoint 2013 solution.

STEP 1: Setup the Environment to Support Bing Maps

The only pre-requisite we have is that a farm admin needs to register a Bing Maps key with the farm (or site or web). I’ll do this using the PowerShell technique outlined on Microsoft’s article explaining how to use the location field type in mobile applications for SharePoint 2013.

Set-SPBingMapsKey –BingKey <Bing Maps Key>
Note: In SharePoint Online, this step is not required.

STEP 2: Add the Pothole Reports List and Script Files

After the farm is configured, I’ll Launch Visual Studio 2013, and create a sandbox solution – I’ve named mine “Pothole Reports”.

Once the project is created, the first step is to add the Pothole Reports list. My list consists of three fields and it has attachments enabled:

  1. Title – OOTB Title field
  2. Report Description – Note
  3. Pothole Location – Geolocation

To add the list, I will use the Visual Studio 2013 UI. It was fairly easy to create lists in Visual Studio 2010, but Visual Studio 2013 provides a new GUI authoring environment that, IMO, makes creating lists even easier/quicker than it is in the SharePoint UI. Also, Visual Studio automatically removes spaces from the Display Name to generate the internal field name so we don’t have to waste time specifying both the ‘Name’ and ‘Display Name’ fields in our schema and/or deal with spaces’ hex value in our code (i.e. x0020). Finally, the Visual Studio list definition UI also makes the Geographic Location field type available to us out of the box, whereas one must otherwise add the field programmatically or through PowerShell.

Now we have our list to store users’ reports. Next, I will add modules to store my JavaScript, CSS, and Image files. This project is going to require jQuery and jQuery Mobile, so I will get the necessary files added to my project. After they’re added, I’ll add the appropriate references in the site master page and move on to create the form.

STEP 3: Create the Mobile Form

We need only 2 input fields on our form – this experience is going to be as efficient for the mobile user as we can make it. The fields on the form will be Description and Picture, and I will render the form using a Visual Web part so that I can easily add this to a page in my Publishing site.

First, I tweaked the master page a bit to optimize for a good anonymous mobile experience. A few of the key changes were to:

  • Add the viewport metatag to auto-scale on the device-width to the head placeholder
  • Hide the suiteBar, ribbonrow, titlerownew, sideNavBox, contentBox, and titlerow
  • Overload the FixRibbonAndWorkspaceDimensions, ProcessImn, and ProcessImnMarkers JavaScript functions to stop SharePoint from trying to dynamically resize the page and from trying to add ActiveX controls
  • Register the jQuery Mobile CSS and JavaScript, and register my own JavaScript files

With that done, we begin form design. I added header, content, and footer sections, and inside of the content section I added the two user controls for capturing description and the picture to upload. The user’s latitude and longitude will be stored in hidden fields that I populate when the form first loads. Here’s a snapshot of the form and a snippet of the JavaScript used to store the user’s location.

var gps = navigator.geolocation.getCurrentPosition(function (position) {

var latitude = position.coords.latitude;

var longitude = position.coords.longitude;

$obj.val(latitude + ‘,’ + longitude);

});

STEP 4: Process User Submission

Inside of my Visual Web Part code, I’ll store the submitted description, picture, and user’s coordinates as a new list entry.

Here is the interesting part of that code:
try
{

byte[] fileBytes = potholepicture.FileBytes;

if (fileBytes.Length > 0)

{

// add the item (longitude x latitude in WKT format)

string[] lat_and_long = userlocation.Value.Split(‘,’);

SPListItem myItem = myWeb.Lists["Pothole Reports"].Items.Add();

myItem["ReportDescription"] = potholedescription.InnerText;

myItem["PotholeLocation"] = “POINT(” + lat_and_long[1] + ” ” + lat_and_long[0] + “)”;

myWeb.AllowUnsafeUpdates = true;

myItem.Update();

// now, attach the picture

addFileToListItem(myItem.ParentList.Title, myItem.ID, potholepicture.FileName, fileBytes, myWeb);

myWeb.AllowUnsafeUpdates = false;

}

}

STEP 5: Review List Entry

After the code above executes, there should be a new entry in our Pothole Reports list with the description and exact latitude/longitude of the pothole. That list item will also have a picture of the pothole attached.

Conclusion

With jQuery Mobile and Visual Web Parts we were able to make an intuitive mobile form through which users can submit work-order requests to SharePoint. Using JavaScript’s geolocation API along with SharePoint’s new geolocation field, the data captured through user submission provides a precise location that is automatically visualized through Bing maps.

From here, it would be easy to setup an event receiver or SPD workflow to send dispatch an e-mail about the new report with a link to the item view form, repair orders could be sent out with the click of a button, tasks could be generated to promote accountability and visibility, etc. The possibilities are endless.

The post SharePoint 2013 – Mobile Forms and Geolocation appeared first on TahoeSmart.

item.title: Five Things to Think About: Accessibility
item.dc:creator: Mark Cleofe
item.description:
What is “accessibility?” We define accessibility as “the extent to which the information being presented is available and understandable by anyone.” One

The post Five Things to Think About: Accessibility appeared first on TahoeSmart.
item.content:encoded:
What is “accessibility?” We define accessibility as “the extent to which the information being presented is available and understandable by anyone.” One might argue that an application should be designed only for the target audience, but it should also be taken into consideration that audience members may have a visual or aural impairment and require the use of a “helper” like a screen reader or translation software. Is the content accessible publicly by everyone or in a controlled environment like a private workplace? In other words, it is important to know your audience.

Your audience may or may not be obvious, but it is important to know who they are and what tools they use. If the product will be used by a very specific user type–an employee, for example–then you only need to consider the tools that are specific to the users in that environment. Questions to ask include, “What age group do our users belong to?” “Do any of my employees have disabilities?” “What are typical helper tools that this group may use?” Answers to these questions may be as simple as “eye glasses,” but some of your users may require the use of screen readers (for the blind).

If the application or web site will be available to the public, it should be designed with the broadest audience in mind. Here are some accessibility issues to consider:

  • Client functions
    • Browser magnification has grown in use since smart phones and tablets have become more prevalent. The availability of high definition on laptops and other smaller monitors have also caused the increased use of magnification in browsers.
    • Opening new windows has had unreliable behavior as tabs have become popular in browsers.
    • Modal windows and dialogs (a.k.a. “lightboxes”) have been known to cause issues with screen readers if implemented incorrectly.
  • Optical equipment
    • Monitors today come in more shapes and sizes than ever before. With high-definition monitors available on laptops, it’s difficult to imagine a user browsing your web site at a full 1920×1080 on a 17” monitor… or is it?
    • Projectors often don’t represent color as intended. Ensure that your important content can be viewed easily when being projected. Use high contrast for text (e.g., black on white).
  • Software
    • Consider the use of screen reading software for the blind. Any images that give context to your content should include textual representation.
    • Some visually impaired users employ additional magnification software to view content on the screen.
    • Some audience members may rely on language translators. You can avoid miscommunication by offering an alternative version of your content in multiple languages so that the user will not have to rely on software. This way, you can be sure to communicate the intended ideas rather than risk losing something in translation.
  • Hardware
    • Mobile or desktop browser? Be sure to make the content compatible across all platforms and enable responsive design on your content if it will be viewed on multiple devices.
    • Will the content be viewed on a TV? With the growing popularity of devices like Google TV, gaming consoles, and smart TVs, web content is being displayed on television more than ever before.
  • People
    • Will your users require another human being to help them? The elderly often rely on younger helpers to assist them with accessing content. Ensure that your content is understandable to all possible parties.

Be sure to also observe accessibility compliance requirements if your audience may include users that have specific needs. For example, the standards in Section 508 are regulated by the government and require that people with disabilities have access to certain types of content.

Accessibility is a critical element in designing anything, whether it is hardware, software, or content. Making sure that users can understand your product helps to reduce miscommunication and calls to the help desk. What’s more, exceptional accessibility naturally makes your product available to anyone, which is the bottom line for most businesses.

The post Five Things to Think About: Accessibility appeared first on TahoeSmart.

item.title: Go Mobile with SharePoint 2013 – the Top 5 Features
item.dc:creator: David Sidwell
item.description:
This week’s SharePoint 2013 Top 5 list looks at the latest mobile features in SharePoint 2013. While we all found mobile support

The post Go Mobile with SharePoint 2013 – the Top 5 Features appeared first on TahoeSmart.
item.content:encoded:
This week’s SharePoint 2013 Top 5 list looks at the latest mobile features in SharePoint 2013. While we all found mobile support in SharePoint 2010 lacking (to say the least), SharePoint 2013 has come a long way. These are the features we see as most important – read on see if you think SharePoint 2013 has finally gone mobile.

MOBILE BROWSER EXPERIENCE
Depending on the mobile browser being used, SharePoint can provide different browsing options – the Classic View, the Contemporary View and the Full Screen UI.

The Contemporary View is new to SharePoint 2013. This view renders in HTML5 and is available to the newest mobile browsers – Mobile IE9.0+, iPhone’s Safari 4.0+ and Android 4.0+. It is a clean view with the goal of providing quick access to lists, document libraries, and other common SharePoint content. The classic view provides backward compatibility for older mobile browsers. In this case, classic means old – it is the same mobile view that was available in SharePoint 2010. While functional, it is meant for a specific purpose, and it is not going to win any user design awards. The Full Screen UI is exactly what the name says – a full desktop view of the site shown on the mobile device.

DEVICE CHANNELS
Device Channels are a way for you to choose how the same content displays on different devices. If you tried to support mobile browsers on early versions of SharePoint you know you either had a single mobile view or you went through numerous workarounds to get browser specific content. SharePoint 2013 cleans it up. Your master pages, page layouts, and style sheets can be mapped to specific mobile browsers, allowing much more control over the display of your content.

While the list of mobile browsers is limited, it includes the popular ones such as iPhone, Android, and Windows Phone. Details on supported browsers can be found on Microsoft’s Technet site.

PUSH NOTIFICATIONS
Say you often work with a SharePoint library, and want to be notified on your mobile device when a new or changed document is posted to that list. Alert functionality has been around for a while and can send you an email or text, but SharePoint 2013 takes it a step further by providing the plumbing so users can receive notifications on their mobile devices when specific activities occur on a SharePoint site. This is a powerful tool to keep users informed of key changes to SharePoint-based sites and business solutions. Imagine you have an idea capture and management solution built in SharePoint 2013. You can now automatically push notifications to the employee who submitted the idea each time the status of that idea changes. This is a great way to engage users and increase overall use of your solutions.

Not surprisingly, the app on the mobile device must be specifically built to leverage this notification feature. Expect more and more apps that leverage SharePoint to incorporate push notifications into their standard functionality.

LOCATION (or GEOLOCATION)
Whether you call it location or geolocation, SharePoint 2013 now contains a geolocation field type that can be included in a list. This has numerous applications, such as automatically logging the location of a user each time they enter information. This is a powerful feature for SharePoint-based applications where mobile users are capturing information through their phone or tablet. You can display this location information via Bing Maps (not Google Maps or other popular mapping services).

There is a notable drawback to this feature. This new field type isn’t available through the standard UI list building tools. Instead, it must be inserted programmatically. Most situations where you will use this field type will require coding anyways, so this drawback isn’t as serious as it initially appears.

OFFICE WEB APPS
Do you find yourself accessing SharePoint-based documents more than ever on your mobile device? If this is true for you or your users, you’ll like the changes to Office Web Apps in SharePoint 2013. Now SharePoint 2013 and the Office Web Apps Server work together better than ever before to provide a higher quality experience for users who interact with documents on their phones. This covers Word, Excel and PowerPoint documents, and the viewer for these documents is now optimized for phones. Could you view these types of documents on SharePoint 2010 using Office Web Apps? Yes, but it wasn’t as user-friendly as it is now. We hope that Microsoft continues to enhance this experience, since viewing and editing documents on our mobiles devices is becoming much more common.

There are changes from SharePoint 2010 with how the installation is done (and how many servers are needed) to enable these features, so make sure your infrastructure and admin teams know you want this functionality.

Of course, Microsoft realizes that access via mobile devices is the way of the future, so they have attempted to add support to make mobile use of SharePoint easy and user-friendly. They’ve given improved out of the box capabilities, like the contemporary view, and powerful tools for site designers and developers to use to provide very custom experiences to different users.

The post Go Mobile with SharePoint 2013 – the Top 5 Features appeared first on TahoeSmart.

item.title: It’s Not Member Onboarding – It’s Member Welcoming
item.dc:creator: Matthew Feeley
item.description:
As health insurers prepare for a wave of new members in 2014, they are investing significant dollars and resources in new and

The post It’s Not Member Onboarding – It’s Member Welcoming appeared first on TahoeSmart.
item.content:encoded:
As health insurers prepare for a wave of new members in 2014, they are investing significant dollars and resources in new and revamped online member portals. So why aren’t more members registering?

We know that online engagement pivots on the days (even hours) before and after a shopper submits an application, so insurers are looking to:

  • Build a seamless experience converting shoppers into members.
  • Leverage mobile resources to engage members at the point of sale.
  • Reduce call center volumes by giving members answers to common onboarding questions.
  • Make members feel like valued customers.
  • Maximize ROI on their member portal.

When thinking through the member welcoming process, consider how you can best leverage all available channels, such as web, mobile, etc. to drive member engagement – and reduce costs through increased portal use and self-service.

The post It’s Not Member Onboarding – It’s Member Welcoming appeared first on TahoeSmart.

item.title: 3 Reasons Yahoo Still Doesn’t Get It
item.dc:creator: Ralph Keipert
item.description:
Just when we thought Yahoo finally found its way again, with its stock price up 40% since Marissa Mayer took the helm

The post 3 Reasons Yahoo Still Doesn’t Get It appeared first on TahoeSmart.
item.content:encoded:
Just when we thought Yahoo finally found its way again, with its stock price up 40% since Marissa Mayer took the helm and its recent decision to team up with Facebook to provide more social features on its website, the announcement of their controversial new policy forcing all employees to work i n the office puts everything back into question. If we ever wondered what might make great kindling for blowing up in the social media sphere, we certainly know now.

I’m sure there are plenty of reasons this policy shift sounds great from within the insulated walls of the executive sanctuary, but from the streets outside it sounds eerily like raising the corporate thermostat to a toasty 90 degrees to get more out of presumably already hard working employees. I’m sure there are a few old timers expressing their delight right now that we’ve stepped back in time about 20 years. Who knows, maybe Yahoo will retain its top talent and get a boost in workforce productivity. We’re not here to judge, but we’ll offer 3 reasons why this doesn’t make sense from our perspective.

Availability of tools, tools and more tools for collaboration.
Skype, Facebook, Twitter, Dropbox. Granted most of these tools have a consumer orientation, but replace the names with Lync, SharePoint, Yammer and SkyDrive (or your own corporate flavor) and one quickly realizes that while the world is moving in one direction, Yahoo has found the flux capacitor and is going back in time. People can talk, share information, post updates, find experts, collaborate and even “see” each other from anywhere at any time. One might argue that office space is becoming a relic of the past.

Innovation and product development are happening globally and around the clock.
Talk to most stodgy old manufacturers or a software company, hmmm… and you’ll quickly hear about global collaboration. Ideation through product launch more than ever is being managed in virtual environments that don’t care about time zone or physical presence, allowing sophisticated ideas to be nurtured, engineered and produced. We’ve seen companies accelerate their speed to market by close to 70%, not by sitting next to each other, but through the use of highly collaborative solutions with well managed processes.

Ideas are being identified, fostered, and implemented independent of physical boundaries.
More than ever, the democratization of ideas flourishes. You don’t need to be a senior executive, or sitting across from one, to have your good idea heard and acted on. We can tell you about a company that identified real savings of over $5M annually by giving its product engineers a platform to collaborate virtually.

Maybe we’re the ones that saw a fork in the road and took it, as Yogi Berra so articulately said. Or, maybe Yahoo just took a U-turn. Here’s what Virgin’s Richard Branson had to say. Let us know what you think.

The post 3 Reasons Yahoo Still Doesn’t Get It appeared first on TahoeSmart.

item.title: Top 5 SharePoint 2013 Social Features
item.dc:creator: David Sidwell
item.description:
When Microsoft announced the release of SharePoint 2013 last fall, the question we heard most often was “what’s new and different?” With

The post Top 5 SharePoint 2013 Social Features appeared first on TahoeSmart.
item.content:encoded:
When Microsoft announced the release of SharePoint 2013 last fall, the question we heard most often was “what’s new and different?” With the official launch expected any day, we’re highlighting some of the new and noteworthy upgrades to SharePoint 2013. This week: a closer look at the Top 5 social features in SharePoint 2013, and how they fill the gaps SharePoint 2010 had with social capabilities.

COMMUNITY SITES
Communities have been standard in social platforms like NewsGator and Yammer for years, and now SharePoint 2013 is adding these capabilities. With SharePoint 2013, you can create communities for members of a project team, an enterprise-wide process, a user group, or any other group with a purpose. Members can comment, reply, and grow their reputation within the community while teams stay more connected. Top contributors are easily highlighted so you know who is active and a leader within the community.

ACTIVITY STREAM / MICROBLOGGING
Microsoft calls this their Newsfeed feature – basically, the Facebook or Twitter-like ability to post comments for others to see and view colleagues’ activities. Employees can follow comments, documents, and communities to keep in touch with what is happening in the areas that are most important to them. For example, when a user you are following saves a document in SharePoint, you see this activity in real-time in your Newsfeed, and can preview the document without opening it. Likes, replies, mentions, and hash tags stimulate conversation across organizational boundaries.

YAMMER
Yammer is not new with SharePoint 2013, but this is the first release of SharePoint since Microsoft acquired Yammer in 2012. Yammer is, and had always been, strictly a cloud-based product, so it makes sense that the initial integration between SharePoint and Yammer will focus on the online version of SharePoint 2013. Office365 comes prepackaged with Yammer Enterprise at a reduced price, so using Yammer and SharePoint together is becoming easier to do. Additionally, Yammer web parts integration is included with the on-premise version of SharePoint. You can expect to see more from Microsoft on tighter integration between SharePoint and Yammer.

MY SITE IMPROVEMENTS
SharePoint 2013 expands My Site’s capabilities to include more personal and professional information, which allows users to find others with needed expertise. My Sites are where users access their personal Activity Stream and keep tabs on everything (people, documents, sites) that they are following. SkyDrive Pro is an enterprise version of Microsoft’s consumer SkyDrive service, giving your employees a location in the cloud to store and share files. Employees can work on files offline and access them from home, hotels, and remote offices.

SEARCH GOES SOCIAL
Microsoft focused on expanding search capabilities in SharePoint 2013, and Social Search is one of the areas benefiting from this attention. Expertise search allows users to find authors of documents that contain material related to the search terms. This allows employees to not only find people who list expertise in a profile, but also those who have demonstrated expertise by developing content. Further, people results and document results can be combined to make the search experience even more user friendly. Other search features include recommendations and higher placement for popular content.

Microsoft has made great strides in providing SharePoint 2013 with rich social capabilities, and leading social platforms like NewsGator and Yammer continue to innovate and introduce new functionality. Companies looking to take social to the next level will need to determine if SharePoint 2013 alone will meet their immediate and future needs, or if a third party product on top of SharePoint will provide additional benefits.

The post Top 5 SharePoint 2013 Social Features appeared first on TahoeSmart.

item.title: Top 5 SharePoint 2013 Search Features
item.dc:creator: David Sidwell
item.description:
This week’s Top 5 takes a look at the improved user and business related search features in SharePoint 2013. In addition, there

The post Top 5 SharePoint 2013 Search Features appeared first on TahoeSmart.
item.content:encoded:
This week’s Top 5 takes a look at the improved user and business related search features in SharePoint 2013. In addition, there are numerous technical changes to SharePoint search which will be covered in a future post.

DOCUMENT PREVIEW
Document preview gives users the ability to hover over search results and preview content without opening the document itself. Users are more productive, since they don’t need to open and search through each document to find what they are looking for. In addition, they are able to scroll through the entire document in the preview pane. In previous versions of SharePoint, this preview functionality was typically accomplished through third party tools or FAST, but it is now included in all editions of SharePoint 2013. Of course, there are limitations. The preview functionality uses Office Web Apps to show the preview, which means two things. First, only Office documents can be previewed. This leaves PDFs and other common document types left out. Second, you must have an Office Web Apps server, which could have infrastructure and administration implications. However, despite these limitations, document preview is a great out-of-the-box feature for search users.

FAST IS BUILT-IN
Although we’re focusing on user and business related search features, we can’t write about SharePoint 2013 search without highlighting the fact that most of the FAST search capabilities are now built-in. So, you can look at it as SharePoint 2013 search combining the best of SharePoint 2010 search and FAST search. This means a much more powerful and scalable search for your users, with more functionality, faster results, broader search capability and more.

VISUAL REFINERS
A refiner is Microsoft’s term for additional filters or criteria that can be applied to further narrow search results. For example, a refiner could allow a user to filter search results to show only Microsoft Word documents or documents created in a certain date range.
